{{Infobox stadium | stadium_name = Alumni Coliseum | nickname = Paul S. McBrayer Arena | image = Alumnicoliseum.JPG | image_size = 200px | location = [[Eastern Kentucky University]]
521 Lancaster Avenue
Richmond, Kentucky 40475 | broke_ground = 1963 | built = | opened = September 23, 1963 | closed = | demolished = | owner = [[Eastern Kentucky University]] | operator = [[Eastern Kentucky University]] | surface = [[Wood]] | construction_cost = $3,244,623 (1963)
(${{formatprice|{{Inflation|US|3244623|1963}}}} in {{Inflation-year|US}} dollars{{inflation-fn|US}}) | architect = Hartstern, Louis, and Henry | former_names = | tenants = [[Eastern Kentucky Colonels]] ([[National Collegiate Athletic Association|NCAA]]) (1963–present) | seating_capacity = 6,500 }} [[Image:AlumniINT04-05.JPG|thumb|McBrayer Arena - Interior (2004)]] [[Image:Alumni06.JPG|thumb|McBrayer Arena - Interior (2006)]] '''Alumni Coliseum''' is a multi-use sports arena located on the campus of [[Eastern Kentucky University]] in [[Richmond, KY|Richmond]], [[Kentucky]]. ==History== Built in 1963, the '''Paul S. McBrayer Arena''' located inside Alumni Coliseum, is capable of seating around 6,500 people in both chairback seats and on wooden benches (8,000 for concerts) arranged in a horseshoe shape, facing a wall at the right side of the arena where staging is usually set up for events. The arena's ceiling is made completely of wooden beams and is believed to be the largest of its kind in existence. It was named for the former EKU Men's Basketball Coach Paul McBrayer who compiled a record of 219-144. The floor graphics were updated for the 2005-06 seasons and the banners were redone to be more unified. The building replaced [[Weaver Gymnasium]], which had been home to the Colonels since 1930. In 2018, [[Donald Trump]] held a rally here, making history as the first sitting president to visit the city of Richmond. ==Usage== The arena is home to the [[Eastern Kentucky Colonels]] men's and women's basketball team, and the women's volleyball team. In addition to university sponsored athletics Alumni Coliseum has also played host to a variety of other sporting events, including the All "A" Classic High School basketball tournament, [[KHSAA]] Region 5 Swimming and Diving Championships, and continues to host the [[Special Olympics]] Kentucky Summer Games. The arena has also hosted numerous musical performers over the years, more recently including [[3 Doors Down]], O.A.R. ([[Of A Revolution]]), [[Diamond Rio]], [[They Might be Giants]], [[Nappy Roots]] and [[The Black Eyed Peas]]. It also hosted the [[Ohio Valley Conference]] men's basketball tournament in 1979. On October 13, 2018 the arena hosted a political rally led by President Donald J. Trump, which was the first visit to Richmond, Kentucky by a sitting U.S. president. The Donald Combs Natatorium, located behind the basketball arena, is the former home of the university's swimming and diving team and is now used predominantly for EKU recreation and the [[Model Laboratory School]] Swim team. The natatorium houses a 6 lane 25 yard swimming pool as well as one and three meter diving boards. The Alumni Coliseum also houses four other basketball courts in an auxiliary gymnasium, an outdoor swimming pool, eight classrooms, the [[Chad Bratzke]] Student Academic Athletic Success Center, and twenty additional offices. ==See also== * [[List of NCAA Division I basketball arenas]] ==References== {{reflist}} {{Eastern Kentucky Colonels men's basketball navbox}} {{Eastern Kentucky University}} {{Ohio Valley Conference basketball venue navbox}} {{Kentucky college basketball venues}} {{coord|37|44|14|N|84|18|5|W|type:landmark|display=title}} [[Category:College basketball venues in the United States]] [[Category:Eastern Kentucky Colonels]] [[Category:Basketball venues in Kentucky]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Madison County, Kentucky]] [[Category:1963 establishments in Kentucky]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1963]]

(${{formatprice|{{Inflation|US|550000|1958}}}} in {{Inflation-year|US}}{{inflation-fn|US}}) | architect = {{nowrap|Culler, Gale, Martell, & Norrie}} | former_names = [[Seafirst Bank|Seafirst]] Stadium
(1994–1999){{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=MGRWAAAAIBAJ&sjid=NPIDAAAAIBAJ&pg=5453,5877925|newspaper=Spokesman-Review|location=Spokane, Washington|title=Indians seek sponsor for stadium|date=October 7, 1999|page=C3}}

Indians Stadium){{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=EzwjAAAAIBAJ&sjid=HfEDAAAAIBAJ&pg=4878%2C310559|newspaper=Spokesman-Review|location=Spokane, Washington|title=Indians rename ballpark|last=Derrick|first=Chris|date=March 22, 1994|page=C1 }} | tenants = [[Spokane Indians]] ([[Pacific Coast League|PCL]]/[[Northwest League|NWL]]) 1958–present

{{nowrap|'''Center Field:''' {{convert|398|ft|abbr=on}}}}
'''Right Field:''' {{convert|296|ft|abbr=on}} }} '''Avista Stadium''' is [[baseball park]] in the [[Pacific Northwest|northwest]] [[United States]], located in [[Spokane Valley, Washington|Spokane Valley]], a suburb of [[Spokane, Washington]]. It is the home ballpark of the [[Spokane Indians]], a [[Minor League Baseball|minor league]] [[baseball]] team in the [[Class A-Short Season]] [[Northwest League]].[http://www.spokaneindiansbaseball.com/stadium/history/ History] at spokaneindiansbaseball.com, URL accessed October 18, 2009. [https://www.webcitation.org/5kcI8gATY?url=http://www.spokaneindiansbaseball.com/stadium/history/ Archived] 10/18/09 ==History== Built in less than four months at the Interstate Fairgrounds, the stadium opened {{Years or months ago|1958}} in 1958 and has a [[seating capacity]] {{nowrap|of 6,803—[http://www.minorleagueballparks.com/avis_wa.html Avista Stadium] at minorleagueballparks.com, URL accessed October 18, 2009. [https://www.webcitation.org/5kcIFUZK3?url=http://www.minorleagueballparks.com/avis_wa.html Archived] 10/18/09}}large for Class A ballpark. The facility was built for [[Triple-A (baseball)|Triple-A]] in the [[Pacific Coast League]], which it hosted for 24 of its first 25 seasons. The parent club in 1958 was the [[Los Angeles Dodgers]], who had just moved out west from [[History of the Brooklyn Dodgers|Brooklyn]] and moved their PCL affiliate, the [[Los Angeles Angels (PCL)|Los Angeles Angels]], north to Spokane. They stayed for fourteen seasons, through 1971, then departed to [[New Mexico]] and became the [[Albuquerque Dukes]]. After one year in the short-season Northwest League as a Dodger affiliate, the Triple-A PCL returned in 1973, from [[Portland Beavers|Portland]], as the [[Texas Rangers (baseball)|Texas Rangers]]' top affiliate. The [[Milwaukee Brewers]] became the Indians' parent club in 1976, the [[Seattle Mariners]] in 1979, and the [[California Angels]] in 1982. The Indians left for [[Las Vegas 51s|Las Vegas]] after the 1982 season and the NWL returned in 1983 and has remained for over three decades. ==Earlier ballparks== The preceding minor league ballpark in Spokane was [[Playfair Race Course#Ferris Field|Ferris Field]], which was about a mile (1½ km) west, on the west side of [[Playfair Race Course]]. Named for city attorney George M. Ferris, its original wooden grandstand was built in 1936.{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=4NVXAAAAIBAJ&sjid=DfUDAAAAIBAJ&pg=6625,9204351 |newspaper=Spokane Daily Chronicle|location=Washington|title=So Spokane ball fans can sit in comfort while diamond stars perform|date= June 30, 1936 |page=1}} Ferris was a former player and manager for the Indians who secured funding from the [[Works Progress Administration]] to build it. A fire in October 1948 damaged most of the grandstands,{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=S_w0AAAAIBAJ&sjid=deUDAAAAIBAJ&pg=5948,6106826|newspaper=Spokesman-Review|location=Spokane, Washington|title=Fire destroys Ferris Field's grandstand, parts of bleachers|date=October 30, 1948|page=1}}{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=HIUzAAAAIBAJ&sjid=r_UDAAAAIBAJ&pg=5648,6415080 |newspaper=Spokane Daily Chronicle|location=Washington|title=Investigators seek cause of $100,000 Ferris Field fire|date=October 30, 1948 |page=1}} and it was rebuilt using concrete and steel in the spring of 1949.{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=0mtWAAAAIBAJ&sjid=yPUDAAAAIBAJ&pg=7226,3466099|newspaper=Spokane Daily Chronicle|location=Washington|title=Ferris Field construction rushed; line-up named|date=April 8, 1949 |page=15 }} Earlier baseball venues in Spokane were Recreation Park ({{coord|47.668|-117.368}}), Natatorium Park ({{coord|47.673|-117.459}}), and the original Twickenham Park.{{cite web|url=http://www.milb.com/content/page.jsp?sid=t486&ymd=20100223&content_id=8120524&vkey=team1 |work=Minor League Baseball |last=Price |first=Jim |agency=(''Spokesman-Review'', Spokane, Washington)|title=Indians stadiums of the past |date=June 21, 2003|accessdate=December 7, 2017}} In 1954, four-year-old Memorial Stadium (now [[Joe Albi Stadium]]) was considered as a potential minor league baseball venue.{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=suVXAAAAIBAJ&sjid=kvYDAAAAIBAJ&pg=7081%2C1313667|newspaper=Spokane Daily Chronicle |location=Washington |title=Memorial Stadium may be used for pro baseball |date=June 15, 1954 |page=19 }} ==Other uses== For three seasons beginning in [[2004 NCAA Division I baseball season|2004]], the [[Gonzaga Bulldogs baseball|Gonzaga Bulldogs]] used the stadium as its home venue while its [[Washington Trust Field and Patterson Baseball Complex|current venue]] was being built.{{cite web |title=Patterson Baseball Complex Dedication on Friday |url=http://www.gonzaga.edu/News+and+Events/newsdetail.asp?EventID=2827&DepartmentID= |work=Gonzaga.edu |accessdate=1 August 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/69aFsBm9W?url=http://www.gonzaga.edu/News+and+Events/newsdetail.asp?EventID=2827&DepartmentID= |archivedate=2012-08-01 |date=18 April 2007 |deadurl=yes |df= }} Their former ballpark was displaced by the new [[McCarthey Athletic Center]]. In 2011, the [[Spokane Chiefs]] hosted the first outdoor game in [[Western Hockey League]] history at Avista Stadium on January 15; the home team routed the [[Kootenay Ice]] {{nowrap|11–2.{{cite news|url=http://www.thespec.com/sports/hockey/article/474454--chiefs-rout-ice-in-whl-s-first-ever-outdoor-game|newspaper=Hamilton Spectator|title=Chiefs rout Ice in WHL's first-ever outdoor game |date=January 16, 2011|accessdate=February 26, 2013}}}} ==Stadium name== Naming rights were purchased in 1998 (and the stadium renamed after the 1999 season){{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=SVhjAAAAIBAJ&sjid=QfIDAAAAIBAJ&pg=2561,5458608|newspaper=Spokesman-Review|location=Spokane, Washington|title=Take me out to the ballgame|date=June 16, 2000|page=2-Weekend }} by [[Avista]], the Spokane-based utility founded in 1889 as Washington Water Power Company.{{cite web|title=Avista Legacy Timeline|url=http://www.avistalegacy.com/|accessdate=10 September 2012}} The venue's first corporate name was [[Seafirst Bank|Seafirst]] Stadium, from 1994 through 1999. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.milb.com/content/page.jsp?sid=t486&ymd=20100222&content_id=8112714&vkey=team1 Spokane Indians: Avisita Stadium History] {{Northwest League ballparks}} [[Category:1958 establishments in Washington (state)]] [[Category:Baseball venues in Washington (state)]] [[Category:Gonzaga Bulldogs baseball]] [[Category:Minor league baseball venues]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1958]] [[Category:Sports venues in Spokane, Washington]] [[Category:Spokane Valley, Washington]]

The '''Banana Boat Team''' or '''Banana Boat Crew''' is a hypothetical pop culture [[NBA]] superteam, consisting of [[LeBron James]], [[Dwyane Wade]], [[Carmelo Anthony]], and [[Chris Paul]].
==History== The Banana Boat team first formed after a photo surfaced of James, Wade, Paul, and Wade's wife [[Gabrielle Union]] on vacation in 2015. Anthony, while not featured in the picture, was on vacation with them at the time, and is considered the 'fourth member' of the Banana Boat Team. The four NBA superstars have been friends since they were children, and have consistently gone on vacation together. <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.espn.com/espn/feature/story/_/id/20161740/how-lebron-cp3-wade-melo-ride-together|title=Banana Boat 2018: How LeBron, CP3, Wade and Melo could ride together|publisher=}}</ref>
In the summer of 2016, Dwyane Wade posted on Snapchat that ‘The Banana Boys are reunited.' Snapchat gave the group their own "Banana Boys" Snapchat filter.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.foxsports.com/nba/story/the-banana-boat-boys-have-reunited-for-the-offseason-of-2016-062816|title=The Banana Boat Boys have reunited for the offseason of 2016 - FOX Sports|date=28 June 2016|publisher=}}</ref>
That same year, LeBron James expressed great interest in forming the super team in Los Angeles with the [[Lakers]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.complex.com/sports/2016/03/lebron-james-wants-play-same-team-carmelo-anthony-dwyane-wade-chris-paul|title=LeBron James Wants to Play on the Same NBA Team as Carmelo Anthony, Dwyane Wade, and Chris Paul At Least Once|website=Complex}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://thelab.bleacherreport.com/brotherhood/|title=Brotherhood|website=thelab.bleacherreport.com}}</ref> Chris Paul also expressed interest in forming the team.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.complex.com/sports/2017/02/chris-paul-playing-with-lebron-james-carmelo-anthony-anythings-possible|title=Chris Paul on the Idea of Him Playing With LeBron James and Carmelo Anthony: 'Anything’s Possible'|website=Complex}}</ref>
In the 2017 NBA offseason, two of the four Banana Boat crew members, LeBron James and Dwyane Wade joined forces in Cleveland. Chris Paul was traded to the [[Houston Rockets]], and Carmelo Anthony was traded to the [[Oklahoma City Thunder]].
On July 23, 2018, it was reported that Anthony would join Paul on the Rockets after signing a one-year deal at the veteran's minimum of $2.4 million.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/07/23/sports/carmelo-anthony-houston-rockets.html|title=Carmelo Anthony Set to Sign With Rockets|last=[[Marc Stein (reporter)|Stein, Marc]]|first=|date=July 23, 2018|work=[[The New York Times]]|access-date=July 23, 2018|language=en}}</ref>

{{Infobox film | name = Baseball's Last Hero: 21 Clemente Stories | writer = Richard Rossi | director = [[Richard Rossi]] | starring = [[Jamie Nieto]]
[[Marilinda Rivera]] | country = United States }} '''''Baseball's Last Hero: 21 Clemente Stories''''' is a 2013 American [[Biographical film|biographical]] [[sports film]]. The movie is an [[independent film]] about the life of [[Major League Baseball]] player [[Roberto Clemente]] who wore jersey number 21. It is the first feature dramatic film on Clemente's life and was written and directed by California filmmaker and [[Pittsburgh]] native [[Richard Rossi]] and stars two-time Olympian high-jumper [[Jamie Nieto]] in the title role of Roberto Clemente and [[Project Runway]] Winner [[Marilinda Rivera]] as his wife Vera Clemente. Rossi searched for some time and had difficulty casting the lead. "I'd find someone who looked like him and had those aspects, but they wouldn't be a good athlete," said Rossi. "I'd play catch with them, have them swing the bat. I didn't think we'd find all of those components."{{cite web|url=http://www.post-gazette.com/stories/sports/olympicfeatures/how-an-olympic-high-jumper-became-clemente-in-indie-film-647531/ |title=How an Olympic high jumper became Clemente in indie film - Pittsburgh Post-Gazette |publisher=Post-gazette.com |date=2012-08-04 |accessdate=2013-09-21}} Richard Rossi appears in a supporting role playing the part of the agent "Birddog," who persuaded Clemente to leave the Brooklyn Dodgers to play for the Pittsburgh Pirates. Clemente made his Pittsburgh debut in 1955 and went on to be named to 12 all-star teams while leading the National League in batting four times, winning one most valuable player award and two World Series rings.{{cite web|title=Completed Roberto Clemente Biopic, Filmed in Long Beach, Set for First Public Screening|url=http://lbpost.com/sports/2000004183-roberto-clemente-biopic-filmed-in-long-beach-set-for-first-public-screening|website=lbpost|accessdate=5 July 2016}}{{cite news|last1=Fenno|first1=Nathan|title=Olympic high jumper paralyzed by freak injury now hopes to walk down aisle at wedding|url=http://www.latimes.com/sports/olympics/la-sp-paralyzed-olympian-20170603-story.html|accessdate=6 June 2017|agency=Los Angeles Times|issue=Sunday Front Page Sports Section|date=June 4, 2017}} ==Theme and structure== The film dramatizes how the Hall of Famer faced racism, dedicated himself to humanitarian work, and died in a plane crash en route to [[Nicaragua]] to deliver supplies to earthquake victims in 1972. The “21 Clemente Stories” are 21 vignettes, each from a letter in his complete name using the 21 letters in Roberto Walker Clemente.{{cite news|last1=Mellen|first1=Greg|title=Film about baseball Hall of Fame's Roberto Clemente to play in Long Beach|url=http://www.ocregister.com/articles/clemente-631156-film-roberto.html|accessdate=December 31, 2015|publisher=Orange County Register|date=August 8, 2014}} "The first “R” stands for Rookie and the last “E” for earthquake, referring to the Nicaraguan quake that led to Clemente's death on an aid mission," Rossi said.{{cite web|author=Carrie Chantler|url=http://auburnpub.com/entertainment/capturing-clemente-film-about-baseball-legend-makes-ny-premiere-in/article_9ee3f3d4-66b2-5943-9f90-5981fc16fdc6.html |title=Capturing Clemente: Film about Pittsburgh Pirates legend makes NY premiere in Auburn |publisher=Auburnpub.com |date=2013-08-29 |accessdate=2013-09-21}} "I want people to learn about Clemente, to feel the emotion of the true love he felt for his family, his fans, his team, and the disadvantaged poor he died helping". One of the scenes in the movie features a conversation Clemente has with a nun. The scene spurred several people to pitch the Pope for Clemente's canonization as a saint. Rossi, a former [[evangelical]] minister, received several messages of support, including a letter showing papal support from [[Pope Francis]] in starting the process {{cite web|last1=Snyder|first1=Matt|title=Saint Roberto? There's a canonization movement for Clemente|url=http://www.cbssports.com/mlb/news/saint-roberto-theres-a-canonization-movement-for-clemente/|website=CBSSports.com|accessdate=5 July 2016}}{{cite web|title=Effort To Make Roberto Clemente A Saint Gets Papal Show Of Support|url=http://pittsburgh.cbslocal.com/2015/01/09/effort-to-make-roberto-clemente-a-saint-gets-papal-show-of-support/|website=CBS Pittsburgh|accessdate=5 July 2016}}{{cite web|title=Saint Roberto Clemente? - Puerto Rico Report|url=http://www.puertoricoreport.com/saint-roberto-clemente/#.VL359Cerb8g|website=PuertoricoReport|accessdate=5 July 2016|date=17 January 2015}}{{cite web|title=Canonisation bid for star baseballer Roberto Clemente tragically killed in 1972 plane crash {{!}} Christian News on Christian Today|url=http://www.christiantoday.com/article/canonisation.bid.for.star.baseballer.roberto.clemente.tragically.killed.in.1972.plane.crash/45940.htm|website=www.christiantoday.com}}{{cite web|last1=Editor|first1=ChurchPOP|title=Saint Roberto Clemente? Pope Blesses Movement for Canonizing Baseball Star|url=http://churchpop.com/2015/01/18/saint-roberto-clemente-pope-blesses-movement-for-canonizing-baseball-star/|website=ChurchPOP|accessdate=5 July 2016|date=18 January 2015}}{{cite web|title=Effort To Make Roberto Clemente A Saint Gets Papal Show Of Support - Pittsburgh|url=http://pittsburgh.suntimes.com/pit-news/7/114/64712/effort-to-make-roberto-clemente-a-saint-gets-papal-show-of-support|website=SunTimes|accessdate=5 July 2016}} from the [[Holy See|Vatican]] through the [[Apostolic Nunciature]] in [[Washington, D.C.]] and from [[Archbishop]] [[José Horacio Gómez]] of the [[Archdiocese of Los Angeles]].{{cite web|last1=Biertempfel|first1=Rob|title=Biertempfel: One man's cause to canonize Roberto Clemente|url=http://triblive.com/sports/pirates/6445006-74/clemente-rossi-biertempfel#axzz383KFD9lF|website=TribLIVE.com|accessdate=5 July 2016}}{{cite web|last1=Adams|first1=Heather|title=Roberto Clemente, the next saint?|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/national/religion/roberto-clemente-the-next-saint/2014/06/17/fdd35ca4-f647-11e3-afdf-f7ffea8c744a_story.html|website=Washington Post}}{{cite web|last1=Stack|first1=Peggy Fletcher|title=Next up for sainthood: baseball icon Roberto Clemente?|url=http://www.sltrib.com/sltrib/blogsfaithblog/58027510-180/clemente-roberto-baseball-rossi.html.csp|website=The Salt Lake Tribune|accessdate=5 July 2016}}{{cite web|last1=Somers|first1=Meredith|title=Off base? Effort underway to make Roberto Clemente a saint|url=http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2014/jun/18/base-effort-underway-make-roberto-clemente-saint/|website=The Washington Times|accessdate=5 July 2016}}{{cite web|last1=Pattison|first1=Mark|title=CDOM :: Catholic filmmaker gets to make movie about Clemente, his boyhood idol|url=http://cdom.org/CatholicDiocese.php?op=Article_138850117127645|website=cdom.org|accessdate=5 July 2016}}{{cite web|last1=Jones|first1=Diana Nelson|title=Saint Roberto Clemente?: Former Pittsburgh pastor seeks sainthood for the Pirates great|url=http://www.post-gazette.com/local/pittsburgh-history/2015/01/11/Saint-Roberto-Clemente-Richard-Rossi-Pirates/stories/201501110144|website=Post-Gazette|accessdate=5 July 2016}} "I've never thought of him in terms of being a saint", said [[Neil Walker (baseball)|Neil Walker]], whose father was a teammate of Clemente. "But he's somebody who lived his life serving others, really. So if it would happen, I wouldn't be terribly surprised by it." {{cite news|last1=McCleary|first1=Mary|title=Remembering selfless baseball great Roberto Clemente|url=http://newbostonpost.com/2016/04/01/remembering-baseball-great-roberto-clemente/|accessdate=April 1, 2016|publisher=New Boston Post|date=April 1, 2016}} Some claim the canonization requirement of a miracle was met on July 22, 2017, when Jaime Nieto, who was paralyzed from the neck down in a backflip accident three years after the Clemente film was released, walked 130 steps at his own wedding to fellow Olympian [[Shevon Stoddart]]. The miracle was predicted by Rossi as a demonstration of the power of God. {{cite news|last1=Payne|first1=Marissa|title=After July ‘miracle,’ Pope Francis reportedly moves Roberto Clemente closer to sainthood|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/early-lead/wp/2017/08/17/after-july-miracle-pope-francis-reportedly-moves-roberto-clemente-closer-to-sainthood/|accessdate=17 August 2017|agency=Washington Post|date=August 17, 2017}}{{cite news|last1=Graham|first1=Pat|title=Injured Olympian Walks at Wedding Despite Odds of Never Walking Again|url=http://www.nbcbayarea.com/news/california/Injured-Olympic-High-Jumper-Jamie-Nieto-Walks-at-Wedding-in-San-Diego-436029563.html|accessdate=22 July 2017|agency=NBC|date=July 22, 2017}}{{cite news|last1=Chavez|first1=Chris|title=Paralyzed Olympian Jamie Nieto Walks at Wedding|url=https://www.si.com/olympics/2017/07/22/paralyzed-olympian-jamie-nieto-walks-wedding|accessdate=22 July 2017|agency=Sports Illustrated|date=July 22, 2017}}{{cite news|last1=Garske|first1=Monica|title=Injured Olympian Makes Good on Vow to Walk at Wedding|url=http://www.necn.com/multimedia/Jamie-Nieto-Shevon-Stoddart-Wedding-San-Diego-Olympian-Walks-Again-436032393.html|accessdate=22 July 2017|agency=NECN|date=July 22, 2017}}{{cite news|last1=Wilson|first1=Bernie|title=Step by halting step, Nieto walks down aisle with his wife|url=http://westchester.news12.com/story/35947944/step-by-halting-step-nieto-walks-down-aisle-with-his-wife|accessdate=22 July 2017|agency=News 12 Westchester|date=July 22, 2017}}{{cite news|last1=Graham|first1=Pat|title=Injured US Olympian defies doctors to walk for his wedding|url=http://www.nhregister.com/sports/20170705/injured-us-olympian-defies-doctors-to-walk-for-his-wedding|accessdate=23 July 2017|agency=Associated Press|publisher=New Haven Register|date=July 5, 2017}}{{cite news|last1=Wright|first1=Matthew|title=US Olympian who was paralyzed in a backflip accident defies doctor's predictions he would never walk again by standing at the alter and marrying his Jamaican sprinter sweetheart|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-4721594/US-Olympian-paralyzed-doing-backflip-walks-wedding.html|accessdate=23 July 2017|agency=Daily Mail|date=July 22, 2017}}{{cite news|last1=Ramos|first1=Father Jose|title=Pope Approves Clemente Canonization Cause, Miracle Mandate Met|url=http://www.standardnewswire.com/news/7684012774.html|accessdate=24 July 2017|agency=Catholic Newswire, ROME|publisher=Standard Newswire|date=July 25, 2017}}{{cite news|last1=Dixon|first1=Michael|title=Could MLB great Roberto Clemente be given Sainthood?|url=http://sportsnaut.com/2017/08/could-mlb-great-roberto-clemente-be-given-sainthood/|accessdate=16 August 2017|agency=Sports Naut|publisher=Sports Illustrated|date=August 16, 2017}}{{cite news|last1=Hille|first1=Bob|title=Roberto Clemente is one miracle from sainthood|url=http://www.sportingnews.com/ca/mlb/news/roberto-clemente-miracle-sainthood-pope-francis-catholic-church-pirates/6vke4346xyl414v3iv82ubydd|accessdate=17 August 2017|agency=Sporting News|publisher=MLB|date=August 17, 2017}} ==Production== Rossi worked on the writing of the screenplay for five years, but his stories originated in childhood. When he was growing up in the West View section of Pittsburgh, he sat in [[Three Rivers Stadium]] and watched Clemente advance the [[Pittsburgh Pirates]] to the [[1971 World Series]]. Clemente's attitude towards his fans made an impression on Rossi. “He used to say it is most important to spend the greatest amount of time doing things you love,” Rossi said. “He would talk about people in mills spending money on tickets for games, and how impressed he was at that. It was before free agency, but I don't think it would have mattered.” {{cite web|url=http://triblive.com/aande/movies/4442273-74/clemente-rossi-says#axzz2d7lVwjPi |title=Filmmaker's Clemente movie a testament to grace, power |publisher=TribLIVE |date=2013-08-14 |accessdate=2013-09-21}} As Rossi recalls, he wrote about Clemente for so many assignments in elementary school (starting in third grade) that one of the teachers finally chastised him for it. Rossi believes that Clemente is just as important to the sport of baseball as Jackie Robinson and thinks that his number should be universally retired like the color-barrier breaking Dodger. He originally planned to make the film with a budget like that of "42: The Jackie Robinson Story," but health problems prompted him to jumpstart production and stop waiting for an elusive check from a wealthy investor. “My doc said ‘these kind of moments are wake up calls…if there’s anything you want to do,’” Rossi said. “I said ‘I want to make my Clemente movie’ which is an odd response. Most people want to go on vacation or tour Europe or something. I wanted to make this film.”{{cite news|last1=Ruiz|first1=Jason|title=Completed Roberto Clemente Biopic, Filmed in Long Beach, Set for First Public Screening|url=http://lbpost.com/sports/2000004183-roberto-clemente-biopic-filmed-in-long-beach-set-for-first-public-screening#.U-u1z1Y2Fj4|accessdate=December 31, 2015|publisher=Long Beach Post|date=August 13, 2014}}{{cite news|last1=ZumMallen|first1=Ryan|title=Roberto Clemente Biopic a Dream Come True|url=http://www.gazettes.com/sports/feature-roberto-clemente-biopic-a-dream-come-true/article_b4857726-2450-11e4-b669-0019bb2963f4.html|accessdate=December 31, 2015|agency=Gazettes Sports|publisher=Gazettes Inc.|date=August 15, 2014}} The actors and technicians volunteered their time and donated their services to the project. The film is a blend of news and game footage along with scripted and acted scenes. ==Exhibition== [[File:RichardRossiClementeScreening.jpg|thumb|right|Richard Rossi (center) at screening of his Clemente film at Vogue Theater in [[San Francisco]]. Pictured with him are two fans of the film from [[Nicaragua]] whose families were saved by Clemente's relief efforts.]]Rossi returned to Pittsburgh to premiere his film to two sold-out screenings {{cite web|url=http://triblive.com/aande/movies/4701278-74/clemente-available-dvd#axzz2enkwPp8k |title=Clemente movie available for short time on DVD |publisher=TribLIVE |date=2013-09-13 |accessdate=2013-09-21}} at the ''[[Strand Theater (Zelienople, Pennsylvania)|Strand Theater]]'' on Roberto Clemente's birthday, August 18, 2013. Ron Carter, owner of the century-old Strand, hosted the premiere. “We have done any number of shows here, but this is our very first film premiere,” Carter said.{{cite web|url=http://triblive.com/aande/movies/4442273-74/clemente-rossi-says#axzz2bzuYMMKS |title=Filmmaker's Clemente movie a testament to grace, power |publisher=TribLIVE |date=2013-08-14 |accessdate=2013-09-21}} After Pittsburgh's premiere, Rossi exhibited the film in New York, Los Angeles, San Francisco, other cities, small art theaters, [[Roberto Clemente High School]] in [[Chicago]], the [[Wild Goose Festival]] in [[North Carolina]], and on DVD.{{cite news|last1=Mellen|first1=Greg|title=Film about baseball Hall of Fame's Roberto Clemente to play in Long Beach|url=http://www.ocregister.com/articles/clemente-631156-film-roberto.html|accessdate=December 31, 2015|agency=Freedom Communications, Inc.|publisher=Orange County Register|date=August 8, 2014}}http://cdom.org/CatholicDiocese.php?op=Article_138850117127645 ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== * {{IMDb title|id=1788355|title=Baseball's Last Hero: 21 Clemente Stories}} * {{Facebook|clementemovie|''Baseball's Last Hero: 21 Clemente Stories''}} [[Category:2013 films]] [[Category:2010s independent films]] [[Category:2010s sports films]] [[Category:American baseball films]] [[Category:Pittsburgh Pirates]] [[Category:Films set in Pittsburgh]] [[Category:American sports films]] [[Category:American films]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=August 2012}} {{Use Australian English|date=August 2012}} {{Infobox stadium | stadium_name = Blacktown International Sportspark | nickname = | former_names = | image = | location = [[Sydney]], [[Australia]] | coordinates = | broke_ground = | capacity = | opened = 1999 | closed = | demolished = | owner = | operator = Blacktown Venue Management Ltd | surface = | construction_cost = | architect = | tenants = | seating_capacity = | dimensions = }}
'''Blacktown International Sportspark''' (formally known as Blacktown Olympic Park) is a multi-sports venue located in [[Rooty Hill, New South Wales|Rooty Hill]], a suburb in [[Sydney]], [[Australia]]. The venue includes two [[cricket]] grounds, which have also been used for [[Australian rules football]], an [[Track and field|athletics track and field]], three [[baseball field|baseball diamonds]], two [[Association football pitch|soccer fields]], four [[softball]] diamonds, administration centers and park land.
It was constructed for the [[2000 Summer Olympics|2000 Sydney Olympics]] to host [[Softball at the 2000 Summer Olympics|softball]] and [[Baseball at the 2000 Summer Olympics|baseball]] events.<ref>[http://www.la84foundation.org/6oic/OfficialReports/2000/2000v1.pdf 2000 Summer Olympics official report.] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20001109071400/http://www.la84foundation.org/6oic/OfficialReports/2000/2000v1.pdf |date=9 November 2000 }} Volume 1. p. 370.</ref> The facilities have since been used as a training and administrative base for the [[Greater Western Sydney Giants]] from 2010 to 2012, and for the [[Western Sydney Wanderers FC]] since 2012. Since 2010 the [[Sydney Blue Sox]] of the [[Australian Baseball League]] have used the main baseball stadium as their home field.
==Facilities== * [[Blacktown Baseball Stadium]] * [[Blacktown ISP Oval]] * Blacktown Softball Stadium
==Australian Rules Football/Cricket Centre Developments== Construction of the Australian Rules Football/Cricket centre which features two ovals for Australian Rules Football & Cricket, stadium, function facilities and Indoor Practice Centre for Cricket commenced in 2008. The official opening of the centre was held in on 22nd August 2009 with the Mayor of Blacktown City, Councillor Charlie Lowles joined by Chief Executive Officers from AFL NSW/ACT and Cricket NSW.
==Greater Western Sydney Giants== Greater Western Sydney Giants (GWS) had a presence at [[Blacktown]] from 2010 to 2014 at which time the AFL moved the senior team to [[Sydney Olympic Park]], [[Homebush, New South Wales|Homebush]] in Sydney's inner west. This move was supported by the NSW Government which spent $45<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.brisbanetimes.com.au/national/nsw/nsw-to-retain-nrl-grand-final-20100608-xsk6.html|title=NSW to retain NRL grand final|date=2010-06-08|website=Brisbane Times|language=en|access-date=2018-05-08}}</ref> million to upgrade the [[Sydney Showground Stadium]] at Sydney Olympic Park providing a new home for the Western Sydney AFL team.
==Proposed developments== As part of Australia's unsuccessful [[Australia 2022 FIFA World Cup bid|2018–2022 FIFA World Cup bid]], the athletics track at the western end of the park was proposed to be developed into a soccer stadium named Blacktown Stadium. The stadium would have had 41,000-seat, a figure which would be downgraded to 26,000 post-tournament.<ref>[http://pandora.nla.gov.au/pan/101001/20100714-0611/www.australia2018-2022.com.au/australias-bid_stadiums_blacktown-stadium---sydney.html Blacktown Stadium – Sydney]</ref>
In 2014, Western Sydney Wanderers proposed to build a centre of excellence, consisting of a training base, offices and a youth academy at Blacktown International Sportspark. As part of the multimillion-dollar elite training base and academy, purpose-built grass playing fields, administration facilities, medical rooms and offices on the southern side of the precinct would be built.<ref>{{cite web|title=Western Sydney Wanderers set to confirm $18 million centre of excellence in Blacktown|url=http://www.smh.com.au/sport/soccer/western-sydney-wanderers/western-sydney-wanderers-set-to-confirm-18-million-centre-of-excellence-in-blacktown-20141204-1201au.html?rand=1417691873628|publisher=smh.com.au|accessdate=9 December 2014}}</ref>
The three-day match between Cricket Australia XI and New Zealanders in October 2015 was abandoned after concerns over the pitch, New Zealand apparently refusing to bat because of the dangerous state of the wicket. In that match, Ryan Carters (209) and Aaron Finch (288 not out) scored 503 for the opening wicket and the match score remained as Cricket Australia XI 503/1 (dec). The stand easily eclipsed the previous Australian record of 456 set by openers Ernie Mayne and Bill Ponsford for Victoria state in 1923–24.
==See also== {{Portal|A-League|Sydney}} *[[2000 Summer Olympics venues]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.blacktownsportspark.com.au/ Official website]

revision.text:
{{Infobox cricket ground | ground_name = Bradman Oval | nickname = | image =Bradman Oval Bowral - fence.jpg | country = Australia | location = [[Bowral, New South Wales]], Australia | coordinates = {{coord|34|28.921|S|150|25.505|E|type:landmark|display=title, inline}} | establishment = 1891 | seating_capacity = 5,000 (with temporary stands) | owner = | operator = | tenants = | end1 = | end2 = | international = | firsttestdate = | firsttestyear = | firsttesthome = | firsttestaway = | lasttestdate = | lasttestyear = | lasttesthome = | lasttestaway = | firstodidate = | firstodiyear = | firstodihome = | firstodiaway = | lastodidate = | lastodiyear = | lastodihome = | lastodiaway = | year1 = | club1 = | date = 31 October | year = 2018 | source = http://www.cricinfo.com/australia/content/ground/56328.html CricInfo }} '''Bradman Oval''' is situated at [[Bowral, New South Wales|Bowral]] in the [[Southern Highlands (New South Wales)|southern highlands]] area of [[New South Wales]], Australia. It was named after cricketer [[Don Bradman]], who lived locally and played at the ground in the 1920s. His ashes are scattered on and near the Oval.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bradman.com.au/library_library_detail.aspx?view%3D14 |title=Bradman library (Archived copy) |accessdate=2010-07-09 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110225001009/http://www.bradman.com.au/library_library_detail.aspx?view=14 |archivedate=2011-02-25 |df= }}</ref> It was added to the [[New South Wales State Heritage Register]] on 23 June 2000.<ref name=nswshr-1399>{{cite NSW SHR|5014211|Bradman Oval and Collection of Cricket Memorabilia|hr=01399|fn=EF14/5819; H00/00082/1|accessdate=2018-06-02}}</ref>
It is an attractive ground, with a white picket fence and an old fashioned pavilion. The [[Eucalyptus macarthurii|Camden Woollybutt]] is the main gum tree species surrounding the playing surface.
Bradman Oval and the nearby [[International Cricket Hall of Fame]] (which incorporates the Bradman Museum that operated 1989-2010) are tourist attractions for cricket fans in Australia, and for people visiting from overseas.
== History == The land on which Bradman Oval is situated was originally part of Glebe Park, granted to the Church of England by [[John Oxley]].<ref name=nswshr-1399/>
In 1883 the Bowral Cricket Club was formed and cricket has been played on the ground since 1893.<ref name=nswshr-1399/>
Bradman first played on this oval when he was 12 and scored 29 not out for the Bowral Cricket Club.<ref name=nswshr-1399/>
Bradman became a member of the Bowral Cricket Club in 1925. During his first season in the [[Berrima, New South Wales|Berrima]] District competition, Bradman scored 1,318 runs, an average of 94.14 runs. He also took 51 wickets, averaging 7.8 and held 26 catches.<ref name=nswshr-1399/>
Another memorable game on this ground was in 1925 when Bradman scored 234 against the [[Wingello, New South Wales|Wingello]] team that included [[Bill O'Reilly (cricketer)|Bill O'Reilly]].<ref name=nswshr-1399/>
In 1947 the "A Glebe" wicket was formally named the Bradman Oval. Later, improvements were made to the oval through the efforts of Bowral Municipal Council, and Gordon Whatman of Bowral personally maintained the wicket area.<ref name=nswshr-1399/>
In 1976 the reopening of a rehabilitated Bradman Oval was performed by Sir Donald Bradman himself in the company of O'Reilly.<ref name=nswshr-1399/>
== Description == [[Image:Bradman Oval Bowral Ellyse Perry batting.jpg|thumb|300px|right|[[Ellyse Perry]] batting, [[Paul Reiffel]] [[Umpire (cricket)|umpiring]] at a women's [[Test cricket|Test match]] at [[Bowral, New South Wales|Bowral]], February 2008.]] Bradman Oval is bounded by Glebe Street, Boolwey Street, St Jude Street and Bowral Street. A large parkland area dominated by a stand of mature eucalypts possibly remnants of the original vegetation. A stand of these on the eastern corner impart a sense of enclosure and offer a gateway to the corner site. A line of maturing quercus occupy the St Jude's Rd boundary, and a line of exotic trees are being established between the eucalypts and Bradman Oval. The park contains a childrens playground with old road roller and adventure playground on the eastern side and is the location of the [[International Cricket Hall of Fame]].<ref name=nswshr-1399/>
== Heritage listing == Bradman Oval is historically significant at a State level through its association with Sir Donald Bradman's cricketing activities, an association which has been reinforced by the recent construction of the Bradman Museum and the name change to Bradman Oval to commemorate national cricketing history. Bradman Oval provides a tangible link to Sir Donald Bradman's formative years. As the former Glebe Park, the Bradman Oval represents the country town parks of the turn of the century which were characterised by a simple planting layout of trees and a few shrubs and reflects a phase in the development of Bowral when attention was turning to the garden environment. Aesthetically, the park's simple layout is further enhanced by the combination of mature Eucalyptus and deciduous trees which enhance the surroundings.<ref name=nswshr-1399/>
Bradman Oval was listed on the [[New South Wales State Heritage Register]] on 23 June 2000.<ref name=nswshr-1399/>
== References == {{reflist}}
=== Attribution === {{NSW-SHR-CC-contains|name=Bradman Oval and Collection of Cricket Memorabilia|dno=5014211|id=01399|year=2018|accessdate=2018-06-02}}
==External links== *[http://www.cricinfo.com/australia/content/ground/56328.html CricInfo page]

[[File:Kentvengland1842poster.jpg|thumb|upright|Poster for the Kent XI v England XI game that opened the 1842 Week.]] [[Image:St Lawrence Ground.JPG|thumb|Kent v Hampshire in 2008 Cricket Week]] '''Canterbury Cricket Week''' was founded in 1842.<ref>''Barclay's World of Cricket - 2nd Edition'', 1980, Collins Publishers, {{ISBN|0-00-216349-7}}, p387</ref> It is the oldest cricket festival week in [[England]]<ref name=ECBCCC /> and involves a series of consecutive [[Kent County Cricket Club]] home matches, usually held in the first week in August.<ref>{{cite web|author=Arthur Fagg |url=http://www.kentonline.co.uk/kentonline/sport/2010/december/14/kent_cricket_fixtures.aspx |title=Kent's 2011 cricket fixtures released |publisher=Kent Online |date=2010-12-14 |accessdate=2012-02-08}}</ref> Since 1847 it has taken place at the [[St Lawrence Ground]], [[Canterbury]],<ref>''Barclay's World of Cricket - 2nd Edition'', 1980, Collins Publishers, {{ISBN|0-00-216349-7}}, p500</ref> before that it was held at the [[Beverley Ground]] in the same city. In addition to hosting cricket matches, it also includes several other events and ceremonies. As of 2017, there have been 166 Canterbury Cricket Weeks held.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ecb.co.uk/news/domestic/lv-county-championship/kent-surrey,315389,EN.html |title=Arafat returns to haunt Kent |publisher=ECB |date=2011-08-10 |accessdate=2012-02-08}}</ref> The week continued through the Second World War with cricket being held on the ground each season.<ref name=times4aug44>Cricket – Canterbury Week, ''[[The Times]]'', 1944-08-04, p.6.</ref>
The politician and journalist [[Bill Deedes]] wrote in 2000: "while the Second World War was on, I consoled myself by thinking that Canterbury Cricket Week, founded in 1842 with its tents and famous lime tree, unchanging in a changing world, was the sort of thing I was in business to preserve."<ref name=tory2dec15>[[Simon Heffer]] (2015-12-02) [https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/cricket/12027874/Christmas-revives-belief-in-crickets-traditional-festive-spirit.html Old Stagers knew how to take cricket to the people], ''[[Daily Telegraph]]'' page 13. Retrieved 2016-01-27.</ref>
==Traditions== Every Canterbury Cricket Week, Kent hosts a Ladies day with prizes being awarded for the best hat on the day.<ref name=ECBCCC>[https://web.archive.org/web/20120325023042/http://www.ecb.co.uk/news/domestic/counties/kent/canterbury-ready-for-festival-week%2C301511%2CEN.html Canterbury hosts festival week], ECB, 2008-07-28. Retrieved 2012-02-08. Archived from the original 2016-11-14.</ref><ref name=ci8aug98>[[Matthew Fleming|Fleming MV]] (1998) [http://www.espncricinfo.com/ci/content/story/74512.html Canterbury and Headingley], [[CricInfo]], 1998-08-08. Retrieved 2017-04-25.</ref><ref name=wisden11>Collins P (2011) [http://www.espncricinfo.com/wisdenalmanack/content/story/518458.html Fascinating! It's Ladies' Day], in ''[[Wisden Cricketers' Almanack]]'', 2011. Retrieved 2017-11-12.</ref> The Kent supporters club lay a wreath commemorating those who played for the county and died during the [[First World War|First]] and [[Second World War]]s.<ref name=ECBCCC /><ref name=ko2aug04>[http://www.kentonline.co.uk/canterbury/sport/canterbury-ready-for-kent-cricke-a14193/ Canterbury ready for Kent cricket showpiece], ''[[Kent Online]]'', 2004-08-02. Retrieved 2018-03-28.</ref>
The [[Old Stagers]] amateur theatre group has close links with Canterbury Cricket Week, originally being formed to perform at the festival.<ref name=tory2dec15 />
==Impact== Canterbury Cricket Week usually has Kent's highest attendance at the St. Lawrence Ground. It was once considered a major commercial and cricketing highlight of the year.<ref name=BBC>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/7533774.stm |title=Canterbury cricket festival |publisher=BBC News |date=2008-07-30 |accessdate=2012-02-08}}</ref> There were concerns that it could be eclipsed by the growth in popularity of [[Twenty20]] but is still considered unique in cricket and is not expected to change.<ref name=BBC />
==2012== In 2012, the 161st Canterbury Cricket Week was scheduled to clash with the second week of the [[2012 Summer Olympics]] in [[London]] leading to fears of a reduced attendance at the Cricket Week. However, Kent Chief Executive Jamie Clifford stated that he believed that it would bring in larger crowds, mainly from people who didn't have tickets to the Olympics.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/cricket/15961214.stm |title=Kent chief executive not concerned at Olympic clash |publisher=BBC Sport |date=2011-11-30 |accessdate=2012-02-08}}</ref>
==See also== [[Tunbridge Wells Cricket Week]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==Further reading== * ''Canterbury Cricket Week - An Authentic Narrative of the Origin and Career of the Institution. Vol I. 1839-1851'' (Canterbury: William Davy, 1865) * Small, E.M., ''The Canterbury Cricket Week - Its Origin, Career and Jubilee 1842-91'' (Canterbury, 1891) * Hough, G. ''Canterbury Week Centenary 1842-1948'' (Canterbury: Jennings, 1948) * Warner, H.W., ''The Story of Canterbury Cricket Week'' (Canterbury: J.A. Jennings, 1960) * Richard Ritchie, ''The Old Stagers: Canterbury, Cricket and Theatricals: An Official History'', OS Publishing, 2015, {{ISBN|978-0993446108}}.

[http://www.olympic.cn/ external link] {{zh icon}} {{en icon}} | oldcode = | year = 1974 | date = | games = Asian Games | location = [[Tehran]] | competitors = 269 | sports = | flagbearer = | officials = | gold = 32 | silver = 46 | bronze = 27 | rank = 3 | appearances = auto | seealso = | website = }} '''[[China]]''' competed in the '''[[1974 Asian Games]]''' which were held in [[Tehran]], [[Iran]] from September 1, 1974 to September 16, 1974 for the first time. This time, the Asian Games Federation conference, which was held ten months before the Games, decided to expel the [[Republic of China]] from the games and accepted the entry of the People's Republic of China. ==See also== * [[China at the Asian Games]] * [[China at the Olympics]] * [[Sport in China]] {{Nations at the 1974 Asian Games}} [[Category:Nations at the 1974 Asian Games]] [[Category:China at the Asian Games|1974]] [[Category:1974 in Chinese sport|Asian Games]] {{PRChina-sport-stub}}

Villa Española|Villa Española]] | embedded = | website = <!-- {{URL|example.com}} --> }} '''Estadio Obdulio Varela''' is a multi-use [[stadium]] in [[Montevideo]], [[Uruguay]]. It is currently used mostly for [[football (soccer)|football]] matches and serves as the home stadium for [[C.S.D. Villa Española|Villa Española]] of the [[Primera División Uruguaya]]. The stadium holds 8,000 spectators and opened in 2002.

(4 September 2004) | championships = | olympics = | world championships = }} '''Fichtelbergschanzen''' are [[ski jumping]] hills in [[Oberwiesenthal]], [[Germany]]. ==History== Original hill was opened in 1938 and demolished in 1972. They build a total new steel inrun in 1974 and again totally reconstructed in 1991. It hosted [[Fédération Internationale de Ski|FIS]] [[Ski jumping World Cup]] events in 1980s and more world cup events in Nordic combined. [[Tobias Bogner]] holds the hill record. ==World Cup== ===Men=== {| cellpadding="3" cellspacing="0" border="1" style="background:#ffffff; font-size:95%; border:grey solid 1px; border-collapse:collapse;" |- style="background:#ccc; text-align:center;" !width="90"| Date !width="69"| Size !width="200"| Winner !width="200"| Second !width="200"| Third |- | 19 Jan 1986 | align=center|K-90 | {{flagicon|DDR}} [[Ulf Findeisen]]

{{short description|Dirt track in Norfolk County, Ontario, Canada}} {{Motorsport venue |Name = Gopher Dunes |Image = |Nicknames = Canada’s Toughest Track |Location = 4385 Norfolk 59
[[Communities in Norfolk County, Ontario#Courtland|Courtland, Ontario]], [[Canada]]
N0J 1E0 |Time = [[UTC−05:00]] |Broke_ground = 1986 |Opened = 1987 |Owner = Frank and Barb Schuster (as the founders of GoPHER Dunes, Inc.) |Operator = GoPHER Dunes, Inc. |Events = Dirt track racing }} '''''Gopher Dunes''''' is a [[dirt track racing|dirt track]] near the community of [[Courtland, Ontario|Courtland]] in [[Norfolk County, Ontario|Norfolk County]], [[Ontario]], [[Canada]].{{cite web|url=http://www.dirt-bike-tips-and-pics.com/gopher-dunes-ontario.html|title=Location of Gopher Dunes|publisher=Dirt Bike Tips and Tricks|accessdate=2011-11-12}} Many of its sponsors are either locally based companies or local franchises of popular restaurants like ''[[Wendy's]]'' and ''[[Kelsey's Neighbourhood Bar & Grill]]''. ==Summary== The track is internationally renowned for being one of the toughest tracks which require [[Physical exercise|conditioning]]. There are {{convert|26|km|mi}} of trails in addition to a child-oriented track that is much shorter - all strategically places on {{convert|20|acre|sqft}} of land.{{cite web|url=http://www.gopherdunes.com/www.gopherdunes.com/About_Us.html|title=Gopher Dunes - Tracks and Trails/Year of Establishment/Founders' information|publisher=Gopher Dunes|accessdate=2011-11-12}} The kiddie (referred to on the official web site as ''pee-wee'') track can only be attempted by motorbikes up to 125cc (e.g., [[Suzuki DR-Z 125]]) and quads up to 110cc. [[Dirt bike]]s can commonly be seen on the track as recreational biking is encouraged along with organized racing. Rider [[training]] is also provided along with memberships. [[CMRC]] Pro National races and Mudfest are scheduled races done by the organized motorsports leagues for the purpose of racing their respective seasons.{{cite news|url=http://www.monsterenergy.ca/CMS/index.php?option=com_myblog&show=ROUND-5-of-the-MONSTER-ENERGY-MOTOCROSS-NATIONALS.html&Itemid=104|title=Round 5 of the Monster Energy Motocross Nationals|last=Rak|first=Paul|date=2009-07-20|publisher=Monster Energy Canada|accessdate=2009-07-29}}{{cite news|url=http://www.racerxcanada.com/news/4873/sturgess-cycle-national-track-tour-gopher-dunes/|title=Sturgess Cycle National Track Tour: Gopher Dunes|last=Brault|first=Danny|date=June 10, 2008|publisher=Racer X Canada|accessdate=2009-07-29}}{{cite news|url=http://www.tillsonburgnews.com/ArticleDisplay.aspx?e=1669602|title=Killough fourth at Gopher Dunes |date=2009-07-23|work=Tillsonburgh News|accessdate=2009-07-29}} It is considered one of the most difficult tracks on the national tour.{{cite news|url=http://www.oxfordreview.com/ArticleDisplay.aspx?e=1677493|title=Dusty Klatt, Teddy Maier tame Gopher Dunes|date=2009-07-29|newspaper=Oxford Review|accessdate=2009-07-29}}{{Dead link|date=November 2010}}{{cite news|url=http://www.directmotocross.com/news/videos/2009/07/rough-cuts-gopher-dunes-national|title=Rough Cuts: Gopher Dunes National|date=2009-07-22|publisher=directmotocross.com|accessdate=2009-07-29}}{{cite news|url=http://www.delhinewsrecord.com/ArticleDisplay.aspx?e=1667692|title=Gopher Dunes hosts the best in the country |last=Robinson|first=Jacob |date=2009-07-22|newspaper=Delhi News-Record|accessdate=2009-07-29}}{{Dead link|date=November 2010}} A "weird" wedding occurred here involving Mr. and Mrs. Nick Zavitz of [[St. Thomas, Ontario|St. Thomas]], [[Ontario]].{{cite web|url=http://www.4wheeloffroad.com/eventcoverage/131_0902_gopher_dunes_mudfest_weird_weddings/index.html|title=Weird Wedding @ Gopher Dune|publisher=4 Wheel Off Road|accessdate=2011-04-04}} They got married in their respective tow straps deep in the mud of the main pit. A trio of quad riders would pull up in front of the [[Pontiac Firebird|Trans Am]] on a [[pickup truck]] chassis and spray the newlyweds with mud instead of rice. The summers of 2016 and 2017 have provided the perfect weather for both professional performers and amateur users alike who generally like the solid performance that the track provides for their vehicle.[https://motocross.transworld.net/news/2017-gopher-dunes-mx-race-report/ ''2017 GOPHER DUNES MX | RACE REPORT''] at Motocross Transworld The warm, dry summers needed for optimal racing are essentially proof that [[global warming]] may be beneficial for Gopher Dunes in the short term even though farmers and the economy will be affected on a long-term basis. Attempts to maintain profitability in recent years have been affected by illegitimate facilities that have opened up within {{convert|30|mi|km|disp=or}} of Gopher Dunes. These improvised facilities on improperly zoned land have ruined the peace and quiet that comes with living in rural Ontario.{{cite web|url=http://www.simcoereformer.ca/2012/06/19/bylaw-changes-take-on-yappy-dogs-dirt-bikes|title=Bylaw changes take on yappy dogs, dirt bikes|publisher=[[The Simcoe Reformer]]|accessdate=2012-09-27}} ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Norfolk County, Ontario}} {{Coord|42.825121|-80.629005|display=title}} [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1987]] [[Category:Motocross racing venues in Canada]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Norfolk County, Ontario]] [[Category:Sports venues in Ontario]] [[Category:Tourist attractions in Norfolk County, Ontario]] [[Category:1987 establishments in Ontario]]

{{Infobox football club | clubname = Highgate United | image = | fullname = Highgate United F.C. | nickname = ''45'' | founded = | ground = [[Lynch Park, Buff Bay]]
[[Portland, Jamaica]] | capacity = 2,000 | chrtitle = President | chairman = {{flagicon|Jamaica}} [[Von Bish]] | manager = {{flagicon|Jamaica}} [[Michael Beckford]] | league = [[Jamaican National Premier League]] | season = 2012–2013 | position = 11th (relegated) | website = | pattern_la1=_red_stripes|pattern_b1=_red_stripes|pattern_ra1=_red_stripes | leftarm1=FFFFFF|body1=FFFFFF|rightarm1=FFFFFF|shorts1=FF0000|socks1=FF0000 }} '''Highgate United F.C.''' is a [[Jamaica]]n [[Football (soccer)|football]] team playing in the second tier of Jamaican football. It is based in [[Highgate, Jamaica|Highgate]], [[Saint Mary Parish, Jamaica|St Mary's]], but plays its Premier League home games in Buff Bay, [[Portland, Jamaica|Portland]]. ==History== ===Recent seasons=== Highgate clinched promotion to the top level in June 2011 under guidance of Calvin Lewis.[http://jamaica-gleaner.com/gleaner/20110602/sports/sports4.html Highgate, Seba join Premier League] – Jamaica Gleaner Lewis was then lured to [[Portmore United F.C.|Portmore United]] prompting Highgate to line-up [[Braxton Hyre]][http://m.jamaicaobserver.com/mobile/sport/Hyre-fears-money-could-foil-Highgate_9949557 Hyre fears money could foil Highgate] – Jamaica Observer as interim before [[Michael Beckford]] took over. They entered the Premier League recruiting seven players from relegated St George's and three from relegated Benfica. Highgate were themselves relegated after the 2012/13 season.[http://www.jamaicaobserver.com/sport/RSPL--Highgate-defeat-Cavaliers-but-out-of-Premier-League RSPL: Highgate defeat Cavaliers but out of Premier League]  – Jamaica Observer ==Achievements== *Promoted to Premier League 2011[http://www.jamaicaobserver.com/news/St-Mary-team-qualifies-for-first-premiership_8942605 Historic Highgate! – St Mary team qualifies for first premiership] – Jamaica Observer *Eastern Confederation Super League Champion ==Head Coaches== * {{flagicon|Jamaica}} [[Calvin Lewis]] * {{flagicon|Jamaica}} [[Michael Beckford]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{Jamaican Soccer}} [[Category:Football clubs in Jamaica]] {{Jamaica-footyclub-stub}}

A '''hippogonal''' (pronounced {{IPAc-en|h|ᵻ|ˈ|p|ɒ|ɡ|ə|n|əl}}) [[chess]] move is one similar to a [[knight (chess)|knight]]'s move. That is, a leap ''m'' squares in one of the [[orthogonal]] directions, and ''n'' squares in the other, for integer values of ''m'' and ''n''. It need not be a 2:1 ratio for m and n. A specific type of hippogonal move can be written ''(m,n)'', usually with the smaller number first.
For example, the knight itself moves two squares in one orthogonal direction and one in the other—it moves hippogonally. It is a (1,2) hippogonal mover, sometimes referred to as a (1,2) leaper.
Other hippogonally moving pieces include the [[camel (chess)|camel]], a [[fairy chess piece]], which moves three squares in one direction and one in the other, and thus is a (1,3) hippogonal mover.
== External links == * [http://www.chessvariants.com/piececlopedia.dir/knight.html Piececlopedia: Knight] by Fergus Duniho and [[Hans Bodlaender]], ''[[The Chess Variant Pages]]''

{{Use dmy dates|date=September 2013}} '''Jamal Al-Gashey''' ({{lang-ar|جمال الجاشي}}; born 1953{{cite book|last1=Reeve|first1=Simon|title=One day in September : the full story of the 1972 Munich Olympics massacre and the Israeli revenge operation "Wrath of God"|date=2000|publisher=Arcade|location=New York|isbn=1-55970-547-7|page=49|edition=1st U.S.}}) was a member of the [[Black September (group)|Black September]] offshoot of the [[Palestine Liberation Organization]] and is the last surviving member of the group of eight Black September members who carried out the [[Munich massacre|massacre of eleven Israeli athletes]] during the [[1972 Munich Olympics]]. He is visible several times in videos of the event, identifiable by his blue and white striped jacket. During the abortive rescue attempt by [[Bavaria]]n border guards and Munich police which resulted in the deaths of nine hostages and five of the Black September members, Al-Gashey was shot in the wrist attempting to aid a fellow Black September member. ==Early life== In interviews, Al-Gashey has said that he was brought up in conditions of great poverty, mostly in the [[Shatila refugee camp]] in [[Lebanon]]. His family was displaced in the [[1948 Arab–Israeli War]], but always harbored a desire to return. Al-Gashey claimed that the injustice of being forced to live in squalor and rely on handouts while the "intruders" were living on his land fostered his hatred for Israel. This led to his joining the [[Palestine Liberation Organization|PLO]] in 1967. He said that during his initial training he felt, for the first time, "truly Palestinian ... not just a wretched refugee, but a revolutionary fighting for a cause."Personal interview, in ''[[One Day in September]]''. 1999. ==Role in the Munich massacre== In July 1972, Al-Gashey was one of several young Black September members recruited for what he referred to as "special training," without having any idea what their target might be. He flew to Munich at the end of August 1972, staying in a hotel and even attending a couple of Olympic events. On the night of 4 September, Al-Gashey met for dinner with the other members of the strike team, along with a senior Black September operative (believed to be [[Abu Daoud]]), who briefed them on their upcoming mission and drove with them in taxis to the Olympic Village. Al-Gashey claims that until that dinner meeting, he had no clue that the team's target was to be the [[Israel]]i Olympians. Although charged with multiple crimes related to the massacre, Al-Gashey and his surviving compatriots never stood trial. Nearly eight weeks after the massacre, on 29 October, [[Lufthansa Flight 615|a Lufthansa jet was hijacked]] by two Black September members, who demanded the release of the three Munich survivors. The jailed fedayeen were subsequently released by the [[West Germany|West German]] government.{{cite news|last=Greenfeter|first=Yael|title=Israel in shock as Munich killers freed|url=http://www.haaretz.com/print-edition/features/israel-in-shock-as-munich-killers-freed-1.322811|accessdate=26 July 2013|newspaper=[[Haaretz]]|date=4 November 2010}} When they landed in Libya, they were interviewed, with footage of this press conference being shown in the film ''[[One Day in September]]''. Jamal Al-Gashey can be seen seated in the middle of the three, between his cousin Adnan (who was believed to be the hostage-taker who shot and killed five of the hostages tied up in one of the helicopters''[http://www.time.com/time/europe/magazine/2002/0902/munich/story5.html When the Terror Began]'' (2002). ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]''. Retrieved 7 June 2008.) and Mohammed Safady. When asked directly if he had killed any of the Israelis, Adnan Al-Gashey simply replied, "It's not important for me to say if I killed Israelim (sic) or not."Press conference, as shown in ''[[One Day in September]]''. 1999. ==Post-massacre life== It is believed that Al-Gashey has spent the subsequent time since his release in hiding in North Africa. He married and has two daughters. He is the only member of the group to consent to interviews, having given a brief statement in 1992 to a Palestinian journalist. In 1999, Al-Gashey emerged from hiding to give a more in-depth interview in the film ''[[One Day in September]]''. Since Al-Gashey believed that Israeli agents were still trying to kill him, he was disguised and his face shown only in blurry shadow as a precaution. Director [[Kevin Macdonald (director)|Kevin Macdonald]] noted Al-Gashey's edgy, almost paranoid behavior throughout the interview, but was able to convince him that the film he was working on would only be truly authentic if Al-Gashey gave his side of the story. During the 1999 interview, he explained,
I'm proud of what I did at Munich because it helped the Palestinian cause enormously ... before Munich, the world had no idea about our struggle, but on that day, the name of 'Palestine' was repeated all around the world.
==See also== * [[Operation Wrath of God]] * [[List of hostage crises]] ==References== {{reflist|colwidth=30em}} {{refbegin}} *Klein, Aaron J. (2006). ''Striking Back: The 1972 Munich Olympics Massacre and Israel's Deadly Response''. Melbourne. {{ISBN|1-920769-80-3}}. *Reeve, S. (2001). ''One Day in September: The Full Story of the 1972 Munich Olympic Massacre and Israeli Revenge Operation 'Wrath of God'.'' New York. {{ISBN|1-55970-547-7}}. * [http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/olympics2000/907614.stm The Munich massacre] (2000). ''[[BBC News]]''. Retrieved 24 December 2009. {{refend}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Gashey, Jamal}} [[Category:1953 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Munich massacre]] [[Category:Palestinian people]] [[Category:Fugitives wanted by Israel]] [[Category:Members of the Black September Organization]] [[Category:Sole survivors]]

{{eastern name order|Balogh Lajos}} {{Infobox sportsperson | name = Lajos Balogh | image = | image_size = | alt = | caption = | headercolor = | fullname = | nickname = | nationality = Hungarian | birth_date = {{birth date|1903|05|10|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Budapest]], [[Kingdom of Hungary]]{{cite web|url=https://www.sports-reference.com/olympics/athletes/ba/lajos-balogh-1.html|title=Lajos Balogh Bio, Stats and Results|publisher=Sports Reference|accessdate=24 October 2014}} | death_date = {{death date and age|1986|10|09|1903|05|10|df=y}} | death_place = [[Csákvár]], [[Hungary]] | resting_place = | monuments = | residence = | alma_mater = [[Budapest University of Technology and Economics]] | occupation = Engineer, architect | years_active = 1922–1944 | employer = | agent = | height = | weight = | spouse = [[Anna Kael]] | children = Anikó | country = Hungary | sport = [[Athletics (track and field)|Athletics]] | position = | club = Műegyetemi AFC (1922–36)
Magyar AC (1937–44) | turnedpro = | coach = | retired = | coaching = | worlds = | regionals = | nationals = | olympics = | pb = Long jump – 7.49 m (1933) | medaltemplates = {{MedalSport| Men's athletics}} {{MedalCountry|{{flag|Hungary|1920}}}} {{MedalCompetition|[[Universiade]]}} {{MedalSilver|[[1930 International University Games|1930 Darmstadt]]|Long jump}} {{MedalBronze|[[1928 Summer Student World Championships|1928 Paris]]|Long jump}} | show-medals = yes | updated = 24 October 2014 }} '''Lajos Balogh''' ({{IPA-hu|ˈlɒjoʃ ˈbɒloɡ}}; 10 May 1903 – 9 October 1986) was a [[Hungary|Hungarian]] athlete and later coach, architect, enigineer, politician and sports official. Achieving his best results in the [[long jump]], Balogh was a multiple [[Hungarian Athletics Championships]] winner, [[Universiade]] medalist and Olympic participant. Beside his competitive sports career Balogh worked as engineer and architect, focusing on sports and training constructions. He was a member of the [[Independent Smallholders, Agrarian Workers and Civic Party]] and was arrested together with a number of other party members with fabricated charges in 1947, when the Communist Party carried out a coup d’état against the ruling Smallholders Party. He was soon released. After retiring from sports he earned a coaching degree and also studied the biomechanics of sports movements. He was president of the [[Hungarian Athletics Association]] for a brief period in 1946 and later became a [[docent]] at the Faculty of Athletics of the [[University of Physical Education|College of Physical Education]]. ==Career== ===Athletics career=== Born in [[Budapest]], the capital of Hungary, Balogh competed for [[Műegyetemi AFC]] – the sports club of the [[Budapest University of Technology and Economics]] – between 1922 and 1936, subsequently he switched to [[Magyar AC]] (1937–1944). Competing in sprint events, decathlon and long jump, Balogh achieved his best results in the latter one, winning four [[Hungarian Athletics Championships]] titles (1928, 1930, 1931, 1933). He also improved the Hungarian national record, first in 1929 to 7.43 metres, then in 1933 to 7.49 metres.{{cite web|url=http://mek.oszk.hu/00300/00355/html/ABC00523/00835.htm|title=Lajos Balogh Biography|publisher=Magyar Elektronikus Könyvtár|work=Magyar Életrajzi Lexikon (Hungarian Biographical Encyclopaedia)|accessdate=24 October 2014|language=Hungarian}} During his university years he participated at the [[Universiade]] – also known then as Student World Championships and International University Games –, winning the bronze medal in the long jump in 1928 and the silver in 1930. Balogh was also present at the [[1928 Summer Olympics]] in [[Amsterdam]]. Allocated to the Group C in the qualifying round of the [[Athletics at the 1928 Summer Olympics – Men's long jump|long jump]], he finished sixth of out then jumpers with 6.79 metres,{{cite web|url=https://www.sports-reference.com/olympics/summer/1928/ATH/mens-long-jump-qualifying-round.html|title=Athletics at the 1928 Amsterdam Summer Games: Men's Long Jump Qualifying Round|publisher=Sports Reference|accessdate=24 October 2014}} thus failed to make it to the final round and eventually ranked 23rd.{{cite web|url=https://www.sports-reference.com/olympics/summer/1928/ATH/mens-long-jump.html|title=Athletics at the 1928 Amsterdam Summer Games: Men's Long Jump|publisher=Sports Reference|accessdate=24 October 2014}} After his retirement he worked as a coach and sports official and earned his coaching diploma in 1953. One of his most notable students is Olympic champion high jumper [[Ibolya Csák]]. In 1946 he acted as president of the [[Hungarian Athletics Association]] for a brief period.{{cite web|url=http://nevpont.hu/view.php?id=891|title=Lajos Balogh Biography|publisher=Névpont|accessdate=24 October 2014|language=Hungarian}} ===Outside sports=== Balogh graduated from the [[Budapest University of Technology and Economics]] in 1931, subsequently he worked for ''Óbuda Bridge Engineering Company'' and ''Budapest Electronic Works''. In 1946 he was promoted to Deputy Head of the Energy Policy Division of Ministry of Industry, however, a year later he was arrested by the Communists with the fabricated charge of conspiration against the state. He was eventually released and worked as engineer first for ''Ganz Electric Works'' (1948–1949), then for the ''Metalworkers' Union of Budapest'' and later for the ''Gheorghiu Dej Shipbuilding Company'' (1951–1956). After 1956 he became a [[docent]] at the Faculty of Athletics of the [[University of Physical Education|College of Physical Education]], a position he held until 1963. As an architect he planned and constructed sports facilities. Among his notable works are the stadium of [[Pécsi VSK (men's football)|Pécsi VSK]], the training fields of the [[Népstadion]] and the facilities of [[Vasas SC]] and [[Budapest Honvéd SE]]. He also contributed to the rebuilding and expansion of the sports center of [[MTK Budapest]] and [[Újpesti TE]]. ==Personal life== Balogh married to [[Anna Kael]], a fellow sportswoman and silver medalist of [[World Gymnastics Championships]] in 1934. Their daughter, [[Anikó Balogh]], became an athlete and competed in the javelin throw. Their grandsons, [[Attila Petőváry]] and [[Zsolt Petőváry]] are former Hungarian international water polo players. ==References== {{Reflist}} {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Balogh, Lajos}} [[Category:1903 births]] [[Category:1986 deaths]] [[Category:Sportspeople from Budapest]] [[Category:Hungarian male long jumpers]] [[Category:Athletes (track and field) at the 1928 Summer Olympics]] [[Category:Olympic athletes of Hungary]] [[Category:Independent Smallholders, Agrarian Workers and Civic Party politicians]] [[Category:Sports executives and administrators]]
