{{EngvarB|date=June 2017}} {{Use dmy dates|date=June 2017}} This is a list of sport venues in the city of [[Cardiff]], capital of [[Wales]]. ==Cardiff Arena== {{Main article|Cardiff Arena}} {{See also|Wales National Ice Rink|Ice Arena Wales}} The [[Cardiff Arena]], also known as the Cardiff Bay Ice Arena, is a temporary public [[ice rink]] that is part of the [[Cardiff International Sports Village|Cardiff International Sports Village (ISV)]] in [[Cardiff Bay]]. It has a capacity of 2,500 for [[ice hockey]] and is the home venue of the [[Cardiff Devils]]. The Ice Arena, which replaced the [[Wales National Ice Rink]] demolished – as part of the Cardiff city centre St David's 2 retail scheme – opened on 6 December 2006, after a number of delays.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/wales/south_east/6199544.stm |publisher=BBC News |date=1 December 2006|title= BBC News:Wales:South East Wales:Cardiff temporary ice rink opens|accessdate=5 July 2009}}{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/wales/south_east/6203652.stm |publisher=BBC News |date=4 December 2006|title= BBC News:Wales:South East Wales:Ice problems stop Devils match|accessdate=5 July 2009}} Cardiff Arena, operated by Planet Ice, is a temporary structure that will remain open while a new arena is built in the ISV.{{cite web|url=http://www.walesonline.co.uk/sports/ice-hockey-news/2008/08/14/ice-hockey-evils-focus-on-plans-for-a-new-arena-91466-21531939/ |work=WalesOnline website|publisher=Media Wales Ltd.|date=14 August 2008|title= WalesOnline – Sports – Ice Hockey:evils focus on plans for a new|accessdate=5 July 2009}} Development of the new permanent rink design is due to start in late September 2010, and work is due to begin in early 2011, subject to planning, with the ice arena to be completed by February 2012. Planet Ice will run the rink as well as design and build it.[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-wales-11121857 BBC News | Planet Ice to build Cardiff sports village ice rink] ==Cardiff Arms Park== [[Image:Bmibaby.com Stand.jpg|left|thumb|
[[Cardiff Arms Park]]
]] {{Main article|Cardiff Arms Park}} {{See also|Millennium Stadium}} [[Cardiff Arms Park]] is a [[rugby union]] stadium situated in the [[Cardiff city centre|city centre]]. One of rugby union's most famous stadiums, it is home to [[Cardiff RFC]] and (until 2009 when they moved to the Cardiff City Stadium) was also home to the [[Cardiff Blues]].{{cite news |url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/wales/1092730.stm |publisher=BBC |title= Arms Park groundsman's dream job |accessdate=17 March 2008 | date=30 December 2000}} Previously the site had two stadiums: the Cardiff Rugby Ground and also the National Stadium. Until 1966 it was also home to the only Welsh first-class cricket club, [[Glamorgan County Cricket Club]]. The Arms Park officially opened on 7 April 1984, but by 1999 the [[Millennium Stadium]], which was the fourth redevelopment of the Cardiff Arms Park site since 1881, had replaced it as the [[national stadium]] of Wales. The future of the remaining Cardiff Rugby Ground has been in doubt since the announcement in 2007 that the Cardiff Blues would be moving to the new Cardiff City stadium.{{cite web|url=http://www.cardiffcityfc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10335~1318602,00.html |title=Cardiff City | CITY AND BLUES SIGN STADIUM CONTRACT |publisher=Cardiffcityfc.co.uk |accessdate=10 September 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120722110941/http://www.cardiffcityfc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0%2C%2C10335~1318602%2C00.html |archivedate=22 July 2012 |df= }} The site has been host to many sports apart from rugby union and cricket, including athletics, association football, [[greyhound racing]], tennis, [[British baseball]] and [[boxing]].{{cite web |url= https://cricketarchive.com/Glamorgan/History/Sophia_Gardens/Post_War.html |publisher= Glamorgan County Cricket Club & CricketArchive |title= Post-war developments in Sophia Gardens |accessdate=17 March 2008}} The National Stadium also hosted many music concerts including [[The Rolling Stones]], [[U2]] and [[Michael Jackson]]. ==Cardiff City Stadium== {{Main article|Cardiff City Stadium}} {{See also|Ninian Park}} [[Cardiff City Stadium]] ({{lang-cy|Stadiwm Dinas Caerdydd}}) is a 33,250 all-seated ground in the [[Leckwith]] area of the city, which is the home of [[Cardiff City F.C.|Cardiff City Football Club]]. Owned and operated by Cardiff City F.C., the stadium also hosts the home matches of the [[Cardiff Blues]] rugby union team until 2029.{{cite web|url=http://www.cardiffcityfc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10335~1645239,00.html |title=Cardiff City Stadium: Logo Launch |publisher=Cardiffcityfc.co.uk |accessdate=8 December 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120809120232/http://www.cardiffcityfc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0%2C%2C10335~1645239%2C00.html |archivedate=9 August 2012 |df= }}{{cite web|url=http://www.cardiffblues.com/33_4357.php |title=New Landmark at Cardiff City Stadium |publisher=Cardiff Blues |date=26 June 2009 |accessdate=8 December 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090629174452/http://www.cardiffblues.com/33_4357.php |archivedate=29 June 2009 }}{{cite web|url=http://wales.gov.uk/location/south_east_wales/latestnews/090406stadium/?lang=en |title=WAG: First Minister visits new Cardiff dual code stadium |publisher=Wales.gov.uk |date=6 April 2009 |accessdate=8 December 2009 }}{{dead link|date=May 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}{{cite web|url=http://www.cardiffblues.com/33_4360.php |title=Cardiff Blues Fans Urged to Walk the Blue Mile |publisher=Cardiffblues.com |date=30 June 2009 |accessdate=8 December 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090715174339/http://www.cardiffblues.com/33_4360.php |archivedate=15 July 2009 }}{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/wales/7002590.stm |title=BBC SPORT |Cardiff teams agree ground share |publisher=BBC News |date=19 September 2007 |accessdate=8 December 2009}} After the [[Millennium Stadium]], it is the second largest stadium in [[Cardiff]] and in [[Wales]]. The stadium is part of the [[Leckwith development]]. A branded sponsor name will be assigned as and when the naming rights sell. The stadium was officially opened on 22 July 2009, with Cardiff City drawing 0–0 in a friendly against [[Celtic F.C.|Celtic]].{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/c/cardiff_city/8012041.stm |title=Celtic to open new Cardiff ground |publisher=BBC News |date=22 April 2009 |accessdate=8 December 2009}}{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/c/cardiff_city/8164021.stm |title=Cardiff City 0–0 Celtic |publisher=BBC News |date=22 July 2009 |accessdate=8 December 2009}} [[File:Inside Cardiff City Stadium.jpg|1000px|centre|thumb|wide|
Inside the Cardiff City Stadium
]] ==Municipal leisure centres== {{Main article|Leisure centres in Cardiff}} '''[[Leisure centres in Cardiff#Channel View Centre|Channel View Leisure Centre]]''' in [[Grangetown, Cardiff|Grangetown]] has been open since 2002. The centre includes three badminton courts, a squash court, a climbing wall, a fitness suite and an outdoor all weather 5-a-side pitch. Other activities available at the centre include badminton and netball.{{cite web|url=http://www.cardiff.gov.uk/content.asp?nav=2868%2C2967%2C3001%2C3707%2C3715&parent_directory_id=2865|date=9 April 2009|title=Cardiff Home, Channel View Centre|work=Cardiff Council website|publisher= Cardiff Council|accessdate=9 July 2009}} '''[[Leisure centres in Cardiff#Eastern Leisure Centre|Eastern Leisure Centre]]''' ({{lang-cy|Canolfan Hamdden y Dwyrain}}) in [[Llanrumney]] has been open since 1982. The centre comprises a {{convert|25|m|ft}} swimming pool, six badminton and five squash courts, a multi-use sports hall, a fitness suite and an outdoor tarmac 5-a-side pitch. Other activities available at the centre include bowls, netball, table tennis, trampolining and gymnastics. Sports clubs using the Eastern Leisure Centre include City of Cardiff Swimming Club and Cardiff Volleyball Club.{{cite web|url=http://www.cardiff.gov.uk/content.asp?nav=2868%2C2967%2C3001%2C3707%2C3710&parent_directory_id=2865|date=26 June 2009|title=Cardiff Home, Eastern Leisure Centre|work=Cardiff Council website|publisher= Cardiff Council|accessdate=9 July 2009}}{{cite web|url=http://apps.cardiff.gov.uk/leisureactivities/brochure_online.php?lang=ENG&brochure_id=1 |date=9 July 2009 |title=http://apps.cardiff.gov.uk/leisureactivities/brochure_online.php?lang=ENG&broch |format=PDF |work=Eastern Leisure Centre brochure |publisher=Cardiff Council |accessdate=9 July 2009 }}{{dead link|date=May 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} '''[[Leisure centres in Cardiff#Fairwater Leisure Centre|Fairwater Leisure Centre]]''' ({{lang|cy|Canolfan Hamdden Tyllgoed}}) opened in 1983. The centre comprises a {{convert|25|m|ft}} swimming pool, four badminton and four squash courts, a sports hall, a fitness suite and an outdoor skate park. Other activities available at the centre include gymnastics, trampolining and soccer. Sports clubs either based at, or using Fairwater Leisure Centre include the BBC football club, Cardiff Triathletes and City of Cardiff Swimming Club.{{cite web|url=http://www.cardifftri.net/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=15&Itemid=41|year=2009|title=Cardiff Triathletes Club Info|work=Cardiff Triathletes website|publisher=Cardiff Triathletes|accessdate=6 July 2009}}{{cite web|url=http://www.cardiff.gov.uk/content.asp?nav=2868%2C2967%2C3001%2C3707%2C3711&parent_directory_id=2865|date=26 June 2009|title=Cardiff Home, Fairwater Leisure Centre|work=Cardiff Council website|publisher= Cardiff Council|accessdate=9 July 2009}}{{cite web|url=http://apps.cardiff.gov.uk/leisureactivities/brochure_online.php?lang=ENG&brochure_id=24 |date=9 July 2009 |title=http://apps.cardiff.gov.uk/leisureactivities/brochure_online.php?lang=ENG&broch |format=PDF |work=Fairwater Leisure Centre brochure |publisher=Cardiff Council |accessdate=9 July 2009 }}{{dead link|date=May 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} '''[[Leisure centres in Cardiff#Llanishen Leisure Centre|Llanishen Leisure Centre]]''' ({{lang|cy|Canolfan Hamdden Llanisien}}), the county's largest, opened in 1987. The centre comprises a leisure pool with wave machine, six badminton and three squash courts, a multi-use sports hall, a fitness suite and mini gym. Other activities available at the centre include gymnastics, trampolining and soccer.{{cite web|url=http://www.cardiff.gov.uk/content.asp?nav=2868%2C2967%2C3001%2C3707%2C3712&parent_directory_id=2865|date=26 June 2009|title=Cardiff Home, Llanishen Leisure Centre|work=Cardiff Council website|publisher= Cardiff Council|accessdate=9 July 2009}}{{cite web|url=http://apps.cardiff.gov.uk/leisureactivities/brochure_online.php?lang=ENG&brochure_id=4 |date=9 July 2009 |title=http://apps.cardiff.gov.uk/leisureactivities/brochure_online.php?lang=ENG&broch |format=PDF |work=Llanishen Leisure Centre brochure |publisher=Cardiff Council |accessdate=9 July 2009 }}{{dead link|date=May 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} '''[[Leisure centres in Cardiff#Pentwyn Leisure Centre|Pentwyn Leisure Centre]]''' ({{lang|cy|Canolfan Hamdden Pentwyn}}) opened in 1989. The centre comprises a leisure pool with wave machine, three badminton and three squash courts, a multi-use sports hall, a fitness suite and an outdoor skate park. Other activities available at the centre include basketball, bowls, gymnastics and trampolining.{{cite web|url=http://apps.cardiff.gov.uk/leisureactivities/brochure_online.php?lang=ENG&brochure_id=32 |date=9 July 2009 |title=http://apps.cardiff.gov.uk/leisureactivities/brochure_online.php?lang=ENG&broch |format=PDF |work=Cardiff Council website |publisher=Cardiff Council |accessdate=9 July 2009 }}{{dead link|date=May 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} '''[[Leisure centres in Cardiff#STAR Centre|Star Centre]]''' ({{lang|cy|Canolfan Star}}) in [[Splott]] opened in 1981 and was taken over, and refurbished, by Cardiff council in 2001. The centre includes six badminton courts, basketball, netball and indoor 5-a-side courts, a gymnasium and a fitness suite. Other activities available at the centre include trampolining and table tennis. Sports clubs based at the Star Centre include the Capital Gymnastics Club.{{cite web|url=http://www.cardiff.gov.uk/content.asp?nav=2868%2C2967%2C3001%2C3707%2C3716&parent_directory_id=2865|date=29 May 2009|title=Cardiff Home, STAR Centre|work=Cardiff Council website|publisher= Cardiff Council|accessdate=9 July 2009}}{{cite web|url=http://apps.cardiff.gov.uk/leisureactivities/brochure_online.php?lang=ENG&brochure_id=41 |date=9 July 2009 |title=http://apps.cardiff.gov.uk/leisureactivities/brochure_online.php?lang=ENG&broch |format=PDF |work=Western Leisure Centre brochure |publisher=Cardiff Council |accessdate=9 July 2009 }}{{dead link|date=May 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} '''[[Leisure centres in Cardiff#Western Leisure Centre|Western Leisure Centre]]''' ({{lang|cy|Canolfan Hamdden y Gorllewin}}) in [[Caerau, Cardiff|Caerau]] opened in 1979 and was refurbished in 2008. The centre comprises a {{convert|25|m|ft}} swimming pool, a gymnasium/fitness suite and an outdoor floodlit multi-use games area (MUGA). Activities available at the centre include basketball, football, gymnastics, tennis and trampolining. Sports clubs based at the Western Leisure Centre include Western Warriors Swimming Club.{{cite web|url=http://www.cardiff.gov.uk/content.asp?nav=2868%2C2967%2C3001%2C3707%2C3714&parent_directory_id=2865|date=26 June 2009|title=Cardiff Home, Western Leisure Centre, Western Leisure Centre|work=Cardiff Council website|publisher= Cardiff Council|accessdate=9 July 2009}}{{cite web|url=http://apps.cardiff.gov.uk/leisureactivities/brochure_online.php?lang=ENG&brochure_id=61 |date=9 July 2009 |title=http://apps.cardiff.gov.uk/leisureactivities/brochure_online.php?lang=ENG&broch |format=PDF |work=Western Leisure Centre brochure |publisher=Cardiff Council |accessdate=9 July 2009 }}{{dead link|date=May 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} ==Cardiff City House of Sport== There is a further plan to develop HOS3 which will provide additional disability and niche sport facility provision to the City of Cardiff and will also serve to help grow the current sports education provision at the House of Sport. The Phase III Hall will extend and build on the principles and philosophies of the two current successful facilities and will adjoin phases I and II, expanding House of Sport coaching centre into new and niche sporting areas. The new House of Sport Hall will be constructed for a capital cost of £1.5m.http://www.cardiffcityhouseofsport.co.uk/ ==Cardiff Gol Football Centre== Gol Cardiff is Cardiff's and Wales' only indigenous 5-a-side and 7-a-side company and launched the country's first purpose-built football facility in Cardiff in January 2006. They were also the first company in Wales to make 3G rubber crumb pitches publicly available. In April 2016, Gol Cardiff introduced innovative video technology which has allowed them to capture up to 10 league games per night, with all clips captured uploaded to YouTube.{{cite web|url=http://www.walesonline.co.uk/sport/cardiff-five-side-football-centre-11354658|publisher=Wales Online|year=2016|title=5-a-side Goals|accessdate=1 November 2016}} ==Cardiff International Sports Stadium== {{Main article|Cardiff International Sports Stadium}} {{See also|Cardiff Athletics Stadium}} [[File:Cardiff Amateur Athletic Club.JPG|thumb|
[[Cardiff International Sports Stadium]]
]] The [[Cardiff International Sports Stadium]], opened 19 January 2009, replacing the [[Cardiff Athletics Stadium]] (demolished to make way for the Cardiff City Stadium) is a 4953 capacity, multi sport/special event venue, offering fully certificated international track and field facilities, including an international standard external throws area.{{cite web|url=http://www.walesonline.co.uk/news/wales-news/2009/01/20/jacko-back-to-his-roots-to-open-city-s-new-sports-arena-91466-22731611/ |work=WalesOnline website |publisher=Media Wales Ltd. |date=20 January 2009 |title=WalesOnline – News – Wales News – Jacko back to his roots to open city's new sports arena |accessdate=2009-06-275 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120123043511/http://www.walesonline.co.uk/news/wales-news/2009/01/20/jacko-back-to-his-roots-to-open-city-s-new-sports-arena-91466-22731611/ |archivedate=23 January 2012 |df= }}{{cite web|url=http://www.walesonline.co.uk/rugbynation/cardiff-blues/2007/11/15/end-of-an-era-for-city-landmark-91466-20112288/ |work=WalesOnline website |publisher=Media Wales Ltd. |date=15 November 2007 |title=WalesOnline – Rugby Nation – Blues – End of an era for city landmark |accessdate=27 June 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120123062428/http://www.walesonline.co.uk/rugbynation/cardiff-blues/2007/11/15/end-of-an-era-for-city-landmark-91466-20112288/ |archivedate=23 January 2012 |df= }}{{cite web |url=http://www.cardiff.gov.uk/content.asp?nav=2868,2967,3001,4662,4664&id=3299&Positioning_Article_ID=&Language=&parent_directory_id=2865&d1p1=1 |work=Cardiff Council website |publisher=Cardiff Council |date=29 May 2009 |title=Cardiff – Home, Cardiff International Sports Stadium |accessdate=27 June 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110609165947/http://www.cardiff.gov.uk/content.asp?nav=2868%2C2967%2C3001%2C4662%2C4664&id=3299&Positioning_Article_ID=&Language=&parent_directory_id=2865&d1p1=1 |archivedate=9 June 2011 |df= }} The stadium houses the Headquarters of [[Welsh Athletics]] – the sport's governing body for Wales – and the [[Cardiff Amateur Athletic Club|Cardiff Amateur Athletic Club (Cardiff AAC)]].{{cite web|title=Cardiff – Home, Sport Cardiff, Sport.Cardiff|url=http://www.cardiff.gov.uk/sport/|accessdate=28 June 2009|work=Cardiff Council's website|publisher=Cardiff Council|date=27 May 2009}}{{cite web|url=http://www.welshathletics.org/about-us/contact-us/ |work=Welsh Athletics website |publisher=Welsh Athletics Ltd. |year=2007 |title=Welsh Athletics – Contact Us |accessdate=27 June 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090107014722/http://www.welshathletics.org/about-us/contact-us/ |archivedate=7 January 2009 }} Cardiff Council has approved a proposal put forward by Cardiff and Vale College and the Cardiff City House of Sport to lease Cardiff International Sports Stadium.http://www.cardiffcityhouseofsport.co.uk/news/cardiff-council-approves-cavc-house-of-sport-plans-for-cardiff-international-sports-stadium/ ==Cardiff International Sports Village== {{Main article|Cardiff International Sports Village}} When complete, in addition to the Cardiff International Pool, the International Sports Village (ISV) complex will provide Olympic standard facilities for sports including [[boxing]] and fencing, gymnastics, judo, [[white water]] events (including [[Whitewater canoeing|canoeing]] and [[Whitewater kayaking|kayaking]]) and [[wrestling]] as well as a [[Snowdome|snow dome]] with real snow for [[skiing]] and [[snowboarding]], an [[Cardiff Arena|arena]] for public [[ice skating]] and [[ice hockey]], and a hotel.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/wales/south_east/7184798.stm|publisher=BBC News |date=12 January 2008|title=Wales – South East Wales – £32m world-class pool is opened|accessdate=26 June 2009}}{{cite web|url=http://www.walesonline.co.uk/news/wales-news/2009/03/21/cardiff-new-ice-rink-to-be-complete-by-2011-says-berman-91466-23201169/publisher=Media|date=21 March 2009|title= WalesOnline – News – Wales News – Cardiff new ice rink to be complete by 2011|accessdate=26 June 2009|work=WalesOnline website}} {{Dead link|date=September 2010|bot=H3llBot}} Some of the facilities at the ISV were used as training venues for the [[London 2012 Olympics]].{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/olympics/london_2012/7275423.stm|publisher=BBC News |date=3 March 2008|title=Olympics & Olympic sport – London 2012 – Olympic training venues – Wales|accessdate=26 June 2009}} ==Cardiff International Pool== {{Main article|Cardiff International Pool}} [[File:Cardiff International Pool '09.jpg|thumb|right|
Cardiff International Pool
]] The GBP32m [[Cardiff International Pool]] in [[Cardiff Bay]] – part of the GBP1bn [[Cardiff International Sports Village|International Sports Village (ISV)]] – is the only Olympic-standard swimming pool in Wales.{{cite web |url= http://www.leisure-centre.com/centredetails.php?RECORD_KEY%28centres%29=ID&ID(centres)=76 |publisher=Parkwood Leisure |title=Cardiff International Pool|accessdate=14 February 2008}} It opened to the public on 12 January 2008 and was officially opened on 26 February 2008 by [[Duncan Goodhew]].{{cite web|url=http://www.walesonline.co.uk/news/cardiff-news/2008/02/27/record-opening-for-new-city-pool-91466-20529954/ |date=27 February 2008 |title=WalesOnline News – Cardiff News Record opening for new city pool |work=WalesOnline website |publisher=Media Wales Ltd |accessdate=9 July 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120820020843/http://www.walesonline.co.uk/news/cardiff-news/2008/02/27/record-opening-for-new-city-pool-91466-20529954/ |archivedate=20 August 2012 |df= }} The building includes two pools: an Olympic size [[List of Olympic size swimming pools in the United Kingdom|{{convert|50|m|ft|abbr=on}} 10-lane competition swimming pool]] with seating for 1,000 spectators, and a {{convert|25|m|ft|abbr=on}} 4-lane [[indoor waterpark]] with [[flume|flume rides]], a beach area with [[water slide]]s, a lazy river and jacuzzi. The centre also has a [[gym|fitness suite]] and studios, conference rooms and a café.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/wales/south_east/7184798.stm|date=12 January 2008|title=BBC News:Wales:South East Wales:£32m world-class pool is opened|publisher=BBC News |accessdate=9 July 2009}} ==Cardiff International White Water== [[Cardiff International White Water]] is a £13.3m Olympic standard canoeing and kayaking centre that opens on 27 March 2010 as part of the Sports Village. It is expected to attract 50,000 visitors a year and play a part in the London 2012 Olympics. ==Coronation Park== Coronation Park, adjacent to Sloper Road, [[Grangetown, Cardiff|Grangetown]] is the home of Grange Albion Football Club, who play in the Cardiff and District Premier Division.{{cite news|last=Pritchard|first=Dafydd|title=Question: Are you playing Sunday league football this season?|url=https://www.theguardian.com/cardiff/2010/aug/05/sunday-league-parks-football-cardiff-local-teams-directory|accessdate=21 April 2013|newspaper=GuardianCardiff|date=5 August 2010}} It includes changing facilities, built in 1997.{{cite web|title=Club History|url=http://www.grangealbionfc.co.uk/7.html|publisher=Grange Albion FC|accessdate=21 April 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140531114343/http://grangealbionfc.co.uk/7.html#|archive-date=31 May 2014|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} ==Maindy Centre== [[File:Maindy Swimming Pool.jpg|thumb|Maindy Centre]] {{Main article|Maindy Centre}} The [[Maindy Centre]] ({{lang|cy|Canolfan Maendy}}) comprises a full size football pitch within a floodlit {{convert|460|m|ft}} outdoor cycling [[velodrome]], [[BMX]] [[pump track]], fitness suite, [[dance studio]], outdoor tarmac 5−a−side pitch and a six lane {{convert|25|m|ft}} swimming pool. The [[cycle track]] (previously known as '''Maindy Stadium''') was relaid in 2006. It was one of the venues used in the [[1958 British Empire and Commonwealth Games]], when the site included a {{convert|400|m|ft}} six lane running track (since removed). The swimming pool opened in 1993. The Maindy Centre is home to several sports clubs, including the Maindy Flyers Youth Cycling Club, Squid Flyers Swimming Club, Maindy Corries Football Club, Maindy Higashi Karate Club, Maindy Triathlon Club, and Maindy Rookie Lifesaving Club.{{cite web|url=http://www.cardiff.gov.uk/content.asp?Parent_Directory_id=2865&nav=2868,2967,3001,4662,3717 |date=9 April 2009 |title=Cardiff Home, Maindy Centre |work=Cardiff Council website |publisher=Cardiff Council |accessdate=27 June 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110609180639/http://www.cardiff.gov.uk/content.asp?Parent_Directory_id=2865&nav=2868%2C2967%2C3001%2C4662%2C3717 |archivedate=9 June 2011 |df= }}{{cite web|url=http://www.runtrackdir.com/details.asp?track=cardiff-m|date=29 June 2002|title=Maindy Stadium|work=UK Running Track Directory|publisher=UK Running Track Directory – Tim Grose|accessdate=27 June 2009}}{{cite web|url=http://www.britishcycling.org.uk/web/site/WCU/tra/News/wcu_130706_MaindyTrack.asp |title=13.07.06 Maindy Track reopens |work=Beicio Cymru Welsh Cycling website |publisher=British Cycling |date=13 July 2006 |accessdate=7 July 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060722122701/http://www.britishcycling.org.uk/web/site/WCU/tra/News/wcu_130706_MaindyTrack.asp |archivedate=22 July 2006 }} ==Millennium Stadium== {{Main article|Millennium Stadium}} {{See also|Cardiff Arms Park}} [[File:Millennium Stadium Cardiff.jpg|thumb|right|
The [[Millennium Stadium]]
]] The city features an international sporting venue, the 74,500 capacity national [[Millennium Stadium]] ({{lang|cy|Stadiwm y Mileniwm}}), where Wales' national [[Wales national rugby union team|rugby]] and [[Wales national football team|football]] teams play.{{cite web|title=Facts & Figures |url=http://www.millenniumstadium.com/information/facts_and_figures.php |publisher=Millennium Stadium |year=2011 |accessdate=3 February 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110608154948/http://www.millenniumstadium.com/information/facts_and_figures.php |archivedate=8 June 2011 |df= }} The Millennium Stadium was built on the site of the former National Stadium, Cardiff Arms Park and was opened in 1999, in time to host the [[1999 Rugby World Cup]], including the final. The Millennium Stadium also doubles up as a venue for other concerts and events such as motorsport's [[World Rally Championship]] as part of [[Wales Rally GB]], with the first ever indoor special stages of the World Rally Championship being held at the Millennium Stadium in September 2005. It has continued to host this annual event. One of the annual Speedway Grands Prix is staged on a purpose built full size track in the Millennium Stadium. The Grand Prix is a round of the World Speedway Championship event. Speedway was first staged at Cardiff White City greyhound stadium during the pre-war era with the first meeting being staged around Christmas 1928. In the early 1950s, a dedicated speedway stadium was constructed in Penarth Road and the Cardiff Dragons raced in the National League Division Three for a short spell. The Millennium Stadium has been selected as one of the football venues for the [[London 2012 Olympics]], according to the chairman of the [[London Organising Committee for the Olympic Games|Organising Committee]], [[Sebastian Coe|Lord Coe]].{{cite web|url=http://www.walesonline.co.uk/sports/athletics-news/2009/06/06/sebastian-coe-plays-up-wales-involvement-in-the-2012-london-olympics-91466-23802605/|work=WalesOnline website|publisher=Media Wales Ltd|date=6 June 2009|title= WalesOnline – Sports – Athletics – Sebastian Coe plays up Wales' involvement in|accessdate=25 June 2009}} ==National Indoor Athletics Centre== {{Main article|National Indoor Athletics Centre}} [[File:National Indoor Athletic Centre.jpg|thumb|National Indoor Athletics Centre]] The city's indoor track and field athletics sports venue is the [[National Indoor Athletics Centre]], an international athletics and multi sports centre at the [[University of Wales Institute, Cardiff|University of Wales Institute (UWIC)]] campus, [[Cyncoed]]. The track facilities include: *200m, 4 lane banked track *60m, 8 lane straight track *120m, 6 lane straight track which finishes outside the main arena.{{cite web|url=http://www3.uwic.ac.uk/english/businessservices/conferenceservices/pages/niac.aspx |work=Uwic website |publisher=University of Wales Institute, Cardiff – Athrofa Prifysgol Cymru, Caerdydd |year=2009 |title=National Indoor Athletics Centre |accessdate=2009-06-275 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090420063902/http://www3.uwic.ac.uk/english/businessservices/conferenceservices/pages/niac.aspx |archivedate=20 April 2009 |df= }} ==Sophia Gardens== [[File:SWALEC Stand.jpg|thumb|
[[Sophia Gardens (cricket ground)|Sophia Gardens]]
]] {{Main article|Sophia Gardens (cricket ground)}} [[Sophia Gardens (cricket ground)|Sophia Gardens]] is a 16,000 capacity, [[cricket]] stadium on the west bank of the [[River Taff]] in Cardiff, about one mile (1.6 km) north west of the [[Millennium Stadium]]. Sophia Gardens is home to the [[Glamorgan County Cricket Club]]. The cricket club has played [[first-class cricket]] matches at the venue since 1966, after moving away from Cardiff Arms Park. A 125-year lease of the ground was acquired in 1995, after the previous leaseholders, [[Cardiff Athletic Club]], moved to their cricket section to the Diamond Ground in [[Whitchurch, Cardiff]].{{cite web |url=http://www.walesonline.co.uk/news/wales-news/2009/06/17/what-the-ashes-could-do-for-cardiff-91466-23894940/ |work=WalesOnline website |publisher=Media Wales Ltd |date=17 June 2009 |title=WalesOnline – News – Wales News – What the Ashes could do for Cardiff |accessdate=26 June 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121006230314/http://www.walesonline.co.uk/news/wales-news/2009/06/17/what-the-ashes-could-do-for-cardiff-91466-23894940/ |archivedate=6 October 2012 |df= }}{{cite web |url= https://cricketarchive.com/Glamorgan/History/Cardiff_Arms_Park/Athletics.html |publisher= Glamorgan County Cricket Club & CricketArchive |title= Cardiff Arms Park – a short History by Andrew Hignell – Cardiff Athletic Club |accessdate=14 May 2008}} The ground was the venue for the first [[test cricket|test match]] of [[the Ashes]] series between England and [[Australia national cricket team|Australia]], played from 8 to 12 July 2009.[http://www.glamorgancricket.com/news_view.php?news_id=1277 SWALEC Stadium awarded more international cricket] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080926165111/http://www.glamorgancricket.com/news_view.php?news_id=1277 |date=26 September 2008 }} From March 2008 to April 2018 the grounds were known as SWALEC Stadium for sponsorship reasons.Booth, Dominic (30 April 2018) [https://www.walesonline.co.uk/sport/cricket/glamorgan-cricket-cardiff-ashes-swalec-14595449 Iconic Cardiff sporting venue renamed as sponsorship deal comes to an end], ''[[Wales Online]]'' Beside the cricket ground is the large sports hall complex of the [[Sport Wales National Centre]]. [[Cardiff Corinthians F.C.]] previously used the area for football. ==Sport Wales National Centre== [[Image:Welsh Institute of Sport, Cardiff - entrance.JPG|thumb|right|
[[Sport Wales National Centre]]
]] {{Main article|Sport Wales National Centre}} The [[Sport Wales National Centre]] ({{lang|cy|Athrofa Chwaraeon Cymru}}) was established in 1972 to provide facilities to help develop excellence in Welsh sport. The institute has indoor sports halls, next to Glamorgan CCC's SWALEC Stadium in Sophia Gardens. Sports activities in the Main Hall include gymnastics, table tennis, [[trampoline]], badminton, [[netball]], basketball, [[archery]], martial arts, fencing, dance and boxing. The site also contains [[squash (sport)|squash courts]] and [[weight training]] rooms. Outdoors, the Institute has an international standard permeable artificial pitch, which is one of the home international venues for Welsh [[Field hockey|hockey]]. The pitch is also used for [[lacrosse]] and football. Their outdoor tennis courts are also used for [[netball]] and [[five-a-side football]]. Welsh national teams that train at the Sport Wales National Centre include the Welsh National Rugby team (on the institute's full-size, floodlit rugby pitch), Welsh National Badminton team, the Women's Welsh National Netball Team and the Welsh National Gymnastic Team.{{cite web |url=http://www.welsh-institute-sport.co.uk/content/public/content/default.asp?ID=4 |work=Sport Wales National Centre website|publisher=Sport Wales National Centre|year=2009|title= ::The Welsh Institute of Sport:: – Overview and History|accessdate=2009-06-275}}{{cite web|url=http://www.welsh-institute-sport.co.uk/content/public/content/default.asp?ID=26|work=Sport Wales National Centre website|publisher=Sport Wales National Centre|year=2009|title=::The Welsh Institute of Sport:: – Overview and History|accessdate=27 June 2009|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090503211305/http://www.welsh-institute-sport.co.uk/content/public/content/default.asp?ID=26#|archive-date=3 May 2009|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}{{cite web|url=http://www.welsh-institute-sport.co.uk/content/public/content/default.asp?ID=27|work=Sport Wales National Centre website|publisher=Sport Wales National Centre|year=2009|title=::The Welsh Institute of Sport:: – Overview and History|accessdate=27 June 2009|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090905210534/http://www.welsh-institute-sport.co.uk/content/public/content/default.asp?ID=27#|archive-date=5 September 2009|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} ==Wales Empire Pool== {{Main article|Wales Empire Pool}} The Empire Pool was an international standard swimming pool building, constructed in the city centre for the [[1958 British Empire and Commonwealth Games]] (hosted by Cardiff). It was demolished in 1998 to make way for construction work on the new Millennium Stadium.{{cite web|title=Empire Pool|url=http://www.coflein.gov.uk/en/site/3065/details/EMPIRE+POOL/|publisher=[[Royal Commission on the Ancient and Historical Monuments of Wales]]|accessdate=21 April 2013}} ==See also== *[[List of places in Cardiff]] *[[Sport in Cardiff]] ==References== {{reflist|3}} {{Cardiff}} {{Sport in Cardiff}} [[Category:Cardiff-related lists|Sport venues]] [[Category:Sports venues in Cardiff| ]] [[Category:Lists of sports venues]]

'''''NASCAR Drivers: Non-Stop''''' was an hour-long [[television]] series that aired on [[ESPN2]] that profiles at least three different drivers during a particular [[Nextel Cup]] or [[Busch Series]] race weekend. The show coincides with the latter half of the [[NASCAR]] broadcast schedule. The show's first two seasons ran on [[FX Networks]] on Friday nights and was known as '''''NASCAR Drivers: 360'''''.
The series of episodes gives the viewer a behind-the-scenes view of what the drivers do between the different race weekends as well as how they perform in individual races. The first half of the episode would show the driver away from the track usually with family and friends, while the last half of the show usually details how each of the drivers perform in each of their race weekend events.
When the show was on FX Network the theme was composed by [[Niels Bye Nielsen]]. Since its move to ESPN2 the show has received a new theme and music, in a slightly faster paced style.
==Seasonal overview==
=== Season 1 (2004) === The first season features [[Nextel Cup]] drivers [[Ward Burton]], [[Kurt Busch]], [[Kevin Harvick]], [[Jeremy Mayfield]], [[Jamie McMurray]], [[Casey Mears]], [[Brian Vickers]], [[Kenny Wallace]], [[Rusty Wallace]], and [[Scott Wimmer]].
*Season 1 Highlights: [[Rusty Wallace]] starts his [[Rusty Wallace, Inc.|Busch Series team]], Kenny Wallace racing in his Busch Series team. Kevin Harvick receives his ring for winning the Brickyard 400.
=== Season 2 (2005) === The second season features [[Nextel Cup]] drivers [[Kurt Busch]], [[Robby Gordon]], [[Kevin Harvick]], [[Kasey Kahne]], [[Mark Martin]], [[Jamie McMurray]], [[Rusty Wallace]], and [[Busch Series]] driver [[Kenny Wallace]].
*Season 2 Highlights: [[Mark Martin]] spending time with his wife and son at their residence in [[Florida]], [[Kevin Harvick]] and his wife spending time with Kevin's crew and other family members, [[Jamie McMurray]] discussing plans on building his new house. [[Rusty Wallace]] in his last season before retiring from NASCAR.
=== Season 3 (2006) === The third season features [[Nextel Cup]] drivers [[Jeremy Mayfield]], [[J. J. Yeley]], [[Clint Bowyer]], [[Casey Mears]], [[David Stremme]], [[David Gilliland]].

{{EngvarB|date=October 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2014}} {{Malay name|Najib|Tarif}} {{Infobox football biography | name = Najib Tarif | fullname = Mohamad Najib bin Haji Tarif | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1988|02|05|df=yes}} | birth_place = [[Brunei]] | height = {{convert|1.70|m|abbr=on}} | position = [[Midfielder (football)|Midfielder]], [[Defender (association football)#Full-back|Left-back]] | currentclub = [[DPMM FC]] | clubnumber = 11 | youthyears1 = | youthclubs1 = | years1 = 2007–2008 | caps1 = | goals1 = | clubs1 =NBT FC | years2 = 2008–2010 | caps2 = | goals2 = | clubs2 =[[AM Gunners]] | years3 = 2011–2012 | caps3 = | goals3 = | clubs3 =[[Royal Brunei Police Force Sports Council|MS PDB]]<ref>{{cite web|title=MS PDB bag 1st win in DST league|url=http://www.bt.com.bn/sports-national/2012/03/28/ms-pdb-bag-1st-win-dst-league|date=28 March 2012|publisher=The Brunei Times|accessdate=31 March 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402213944/http://www.bt.com.bn/sports-national/2012/03/28/ms-pdb-bag-1st-win-dst-league|archivedate=2 April 2015|df=dmy-all}}</ref> | years4 = 2012– | caps4 =67 | goals4 =0 | clubs4 =[[DPMM FC]] | nationalyears1= 2005–2014 | nationalcaps1= | nationalgoals1= | nationalteam1= [[Brunei national under-21 football team|Brunei U21]] | nationalyears3= 2011 | nationalcaps3=5 | nationalgoals3=1 | nationalteam3= [[Brunei national under-23 football team|Brunei U23]] | nationalyears2= 2008– | nationalcaps2= 18| nationalgoals2= 1 | nationalteam2= [[Brunei national football team|Brunei]] | club-update = 1 October 2018 | ntupdate = 3 September 2018 }}
'''Mohamad Najib bin Haji Tarif''' is a [[Brunei]]an [[association football|footballer]] who plays for [[DPMM FC]] as a [[midfielder]] or [[Defender (association football)#Full-back|left-sided full-back]].<ref>{{cite web |title=N. Tarif|url=https://int.soccerway.com/players/najib-tarif/241515/|date=|publisher=Soccerway|accessdate=31 March 2015}}</ref>
==Club career== Starting out with the likes of NBT FC and [[AM Gunners]] of the [[Brunei Premier League]], Najib's performances at the [[2012 Hassanal Bolkiah Trophy]] as team captain prompted a move from [[Royal Brunei Police Force Sports Council|MS PDB]] to Brunei's only professional club, DPMM.<ref>{{cite web|title=DPMM FC get fresh legs|url=http://www.bt.com.bn/sports-national/2012/04/05/dpmm-fc-get-fresh-legs|date=5 April 2012|publisher=The Brunei Times|accessdate=31 March 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160605091412/http://www.bt.com.bn/sports-national/2012/04/05/dpmm-fc-get-fresh-legs|archivedate=5 June 2016|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
After appearing only seven times in the [[2015 S.League|2015 season]], his club head coach [[Steve Kean]] advised him to switch to the left-back position for him to gain playing time (as he has done to [[Helmi Zambin]] and [[Aminuddin Zakwan Tahir]]). A season-ending injury to first-choice [[Sairol Sahari]] meant that he would be relied on much more heavily in [[2016 S.League|2016]].<ref>{{cite web |title=Sairol out for the season|url=http://www.bt.com.bn/sports-national/2016/04/28/sairol-out-season|date=28 April 2016|publisher=The Brunei Times|accessdate=28 April 2016}}</ref>
Najib became the starting left-back for DPMM's [[2017 DPMM FC season|2017 campaign]] which ended in a disappointing 8th place, leading to the dismissal of coach [[Steve Kean]].<ref>{{cite web |title=DPMM FC AND GARENA YOUNG LIONS SHARE SPOILS|url=https://www.brusports.com/2017/05/14/dpmm-fc-and-garena-young-lions-share-spoils/|date=14 May 2017|publisher=BruSports News|accessdate=31 August 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Steve Kean, One-on-one: The reduction of foreign players in the S.League is "hard to understand"|url=https://www.fourfourtwo.com/sg/features/steve-kean-one-one-reduction-foreign-players-sleague-hard-understand|date=20 December 2017|publisher=[[FourFourTwo]] Singapore|accessdate=31 August 2018}}</ref> He was back on the sidelines with the arrival of [[Suhaimi Anak Sulau]] in the [[2018 Singapore Premier League|following season]].<ref>{{cite web |title=Behe and Iggy strike for Warriors but DPMM come back to earn SG Cup dra|url=https://www.fourfourtwo.com/sg/features/behe-and-iggy-strike-warriors-dpmm-come-back-earn-sg-cup-draw?page=0%2C1|date=23 August 2018|publisher=[[FourFourTwo]] Singapore|accessdate=31 August 2018}}</ref>
==International career==
Najib has played for [[Brunei national under-21 football team|Brunei Under-21]] since 2005,<ref>{{cite web |title=ASEAN U-21 Championship 2005 (Piala Hassanal Bolkiah)|url=http://www.rsssf.com/tablesa/asean-u21-05.html|date=22 June 2005|publisher=Rec.Sport.Soccer Statistics Foundation|accessdate=31 March 2015}}</ref> and is the only player to have played in 4 [[Hassanal Bolkiah Trophy|Hassanal Bolkiah tournaments]], winning the trophy in 2012. He regards his injury-time free-kick against [[Cambodia national under-21 football team|Cambodia]] in that year's opening match as the best goal he has ever scored.<ref>{{cite web|title=Brunei skipper: It's the best goal I've ever scored|url=http://www.bt.com.bn/sports-national/2012/02/27/brunei-skipper-its-best-goal-ive-ever-scored|date=27 February 2012|publisher=The Brunei Times|accessdate=31 March 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402215218/http://www.bt.com.bn/sports-national/2012/02/27/brunei-skipper-its-best-goal-ive-ever-scored|archivedate=2 April 2015|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
Najib scored in [[Brunei national under-23 football team|Brunei Under-23]]'s first match against [[Timor-Leste national under-23 football team|Timor-Leste]] at the [[Football at the 2011 Southeast Asian Games|2011 SEA Games football tournament]], but the team lost 1–2. He then played in all five matches as Brunei finished fifth in their group.
Najib's full international debut for the [[Brunei national football team|Wasps]] came in the [[2008 AFC Challenge Cup qualification]] held in the [[Philippines]] where he played in all three games. He was also ever-present for Brunei's [[AFF Suzuki Cup]] qualifying campaigns in [[2012 AFF Championship qualification|2012]] and [[2014 AFF Championship qualification|2014]]. For the [[2016 AFF Championship qualification|2016 edition]] he was deployed at left-back, but did not finish the game due to injury which would keep him out of the rest of the games.<ref>{{cite web |title=Fatigue, injuries contribute to loss|url=http://www.bt.com.bn/sports-national/2016/10/24/fatigue-injuries-contribute-loss|date=24 October 2016|publisher=The Brunei Times|accessdate=24 October 2016}}</ref>
Najib was in the list for the [[2016 AFC Solidarity Cup]] but initially did not travel with the rest of the squad.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bt.com.bn/sports-national/2016/11/01/helmi-azwan-join-team-afc-solidarity-cup|title=Helmi, Azwan join team for AFC Solidarity Cup|publisher=The Brunei Times|date=1 November 2016|deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161101103139/http://www.bt.com.bn/sports-national/2016/11/01/helmi-azwan-join-team-afc-solidarity-cup|archivedate=1 November 2016|accessdate=15 November 2016}}</ref> Nevertheless, he recovered and made the starting lineup for the opening match, and kept his place at left-back for the whole tournament as Brunei finished in fourth place.<ref>{{cite web |title=Laos claim AFC Solidarity Cup third place|url=http://www.the-afc.com/afc-solidarity-cup-2016/laos-claim-afc-solidarity-cup-third-place|date=14 November 2016|publisher=Asian Football Confederation|accessdate=15 November 2016}}</ref>
Najib linked up with the Brunei national team for the two-legged [[2018 AFF Championship qualification|2018 AFF Suzuki Cup qualifying]] matches against [[Timor-Leste national football team|Timor-Leste]] in early September 2018.<ref>{{cite web |title=Minister urges national team to make impact at AFF Suzuki Cup qualifier|url=https://borneobulletin.com.bn/minister-urges-national-team-to-make-impact-at-aff-suzuki-cup-qualifier/|date=30 August 2018|publisher=Borneo Bulletin|accessdate=31 August 2018}}</ref> He started the first leg at left-back in a 3–1 loss on 1 September in [[Kuala Lumpur]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.foxsportsasia.com/football/aff-suzuki-cup-football/935614/timor-leste-a-step-closer-to-reaching-aff-suzuki-cup/|title=Timor Leste a step closer to reaching AFF Suzuki Cup|publisher=[[Fox Sports Asia]]|date=2 September 2018|accessdate=11 September 2018}}</ref> He kept his place in a more advanced role on the return leg at [[Hassanal Bolkiah National Stadium]] a week later and scored the only goal of the game.<ref>{{cite web |title=Brunei win 1-0 against Timor Leste but miss out on AFF final round|url=https://borneobulletin.com.bn/brunei-win-1-0-against-timor-leste-but-miss-out-on-aff-final-round/|date=9 September 2018|publisher=Borneo Bulletin|accessdate=11 September 2018}}</ref> His winning goal gave Brunei their first ever home win for an international game, but the scoreline was not enough to qualify for the Suzuki Cup competition proper.

page.title: National Olympic Committee of the Azerbaijani Republic

revision.text:
{{Infobox National Olympic Committee | title = National Olympic Committee of the Republic of Azerbaijan | logo = National Olympic Committee of the Azerbaijani Republic logo.svg | size = 150px | country = Azerbaijan | code = AZE | created = 1992 | recognized = 1993 | association = EOC | headquarters = [[Baku]], [[Azerbaijan]] | president = [[Ilham Aliyev]] | secretary general = [[Agadjan Abiyev]] | website = [http://www.noc-aze.org/ www.noc-aze.org] }} '''The National Olympic Committee of the Republic of Azerbaijan''' ([[Azerbaijani language|Azerbaijani:]] Azərbaycan Milli Olimpiya Komitəsi) (AZMOC) - is an independent public organization, with a status of a legal entity, which passed registration in the [[Ministry of Justice (Azerbaijan)|Ministry of Justice of the Azerbaijani Republic]]. Charter of the organization is recognized by [[International Olympic Committee|IOC]], in 1993. The organization represents the country at the international [[Olympic Games]]. It acts on the basis of the [[Olympic Charter]] and also the Law of the [[Azerbaijan|Azerbaijani Republic]] about enterprises and public organizations.<ref>{{Cite news | title = Olympic movement | url=http://www.azerbaijans.com/content_711_en.html | publisher=azerbaijans.com | date= | accessdate = }}</ref> [[Ilham Aliyev]] – the President of the Azerbaijani Republic, is the president of the committee since 1997.<ref>{{Cite news |title = Ilham Heydar oglu Aliyev |url = http://en.president.az/president/biography/ |publisher = president.az |date = |accessdate = |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20150120082618/http://en.president.az/president/biography |archivedate = 2015-01-20 |df = }}</ref>
==General information== The National Olympic Committee of Azerbaijan was established in 1992 and recognized by the International Olympic Committee in 1993.
For the first time Azerbaijan took part at the Olympic Games as an independent state in 1996 and since then sends sportsmen to all Olympic Games.
Earlier, Azerbaijani athletes competed in the Olympic Games in the team of the [[Soviet Union]] from 1952 to 1988, but after a collapse of the Soviet Union, Azerbaijan became a part of the [[Unified Team at the Olympics]] since 1992.<ref>{{Cite news | title = ИСТОРИЯ СПОРТА АЗЕРБАЙДЖАНА | url=http://www.azerbaijan.az/portal/Society/Sport/sport_r.html | publisher=azerbaijan.az | date= | accessdate = }}</ref>
Azerbaijani sportsmen won, in sum, sixteen medals at the [[Summer Olympic Games]], in [[Greco-Roman wrestling]], [[shooting sport]], [[boxing]] and [[judo]]. At the [[Winter Olympic Games]] Azerbaijani sportsmen couldn’t win any medal.
Chingiz Huseynzade, vice-president of the National Olympic Committee of Azerbaijan, was chosen to membership of "Preparation Commission for the Olympic Games", and Aghajan Abiyev,a secretary general, was chosen to the “Technical Membership” Commission, at the XXVII General Assembly of the [[European Olympic Committees|European Olympic Committee]].
==Main goals and targets== The main goal of the National Olympic Committee of Azerbaijan is development and defense of the Olympic movement in Azerbaijan on the basis of the Olympic Charter.<ref>{{Cite news | title = The functions and duties of the National Olympic Committee | url=http://www.azerbaijan.az/portal/Society/Organizations/publicOrganizations_02_e.html | publisher=azerbaijan.az | date= | accessdate = }}</ref>
==Leadership of the National Olympic Committee of Azerbaijan== 1.President – [[Ilham Aliyev]]
2.Vice-President – Chingiz Huseynzada
3.Vice-President – Azad Rahimov
4.Vice-President – Khazar Isayev
5.Secretary General – Aghajan Abiyev
6.Deputy Secretary General – Azer Aliyev
==Structure== * The General Assembly (includes 133 people) * Executive Committee (includes 17 people) * The President
==Social media== The AZMOC is present on [[social media]], with the Press Office of the Committee running an official [[Facebook]]<ref>{{cite web|url=https://web.facebook.com/nocazerbaijan/|script-title= Azerbaijan Olympic on Facebook|trans-title=|language=|publisher=Facebook|date=|accessdate=}}</ref> page, as well as [[Twitter]]<ref>{{cite web|url=https://twitter.com/nocazerbaijan|script-title= Azerbaijan Olympic on Twitter|trans-title=|language=|publisher=Twitter|date=|accessdate=}}</ref> and [[Instagram]]<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.instagram.com/noc.azerbaijan/|script-title= Azerbaijan Olympic on Instagram|trans-title=|language=|publisher=Instagram|date=|accessdate=}}</ref> accounts. The AZMOC is also present on [[YouTube]] with its own channel.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCAD0sVhftaAUdFktUWfi7cQ|script-title= Azerbaijan Olympic on YouTube|trans-title=|language=|publisher=YouTube|date=|accessdate=}}</ref>
==See also== * [[Azerbaijan at the Olympics]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.noc-aze.org Official website]
{{EOC}} {{Sports governing bodies in Azerbaijan}}
[[Category:National Olympic Committees|Azerbaijan]] [[Category:Azerbaijan at the Olympics]] [[Category:Sports governing bodies in Azerbaijan|Oly]] [[Category:1992 establishments in Azerbaijan]] [[Category:Sports organisations established in 1992]]
{{Olympic-org-stub}} {{azerbaijan-sport-stub}}

revision.text:
[[File:Petzl croll.JPG|thumb|400px|A Petzl Croll with the gate closed, open and with a rope locked in place.]] A '''Petzl Croll''' is an [[Ascender (climbing)|ascending device]]<ref>[http://www.petzl.com/en/outdoor/ascenders-0/croll Petzl Sport - Croll Chest Ascender]</ref> used in caving and industrial rope access made by the French company [[Petzl]]. Its name comes from the town [[Crolles]] where Petzl's company headquarters are located but might also be a reference to the nearby cave system of the [[Dent de Crolles]], the exploration of which triggered a lot of technical effort leading to innovation in caving equipment.
==Usage== The Croll is normally used in the chest position and in conjunction with an upper ascender or [[Jumar]]. This configuration allows a climber, caver or rope access worker to rapidly ascend a rope.
==History== In 1968 Bruno Dressler asked [[Fernand Petzl]], who worked as a metals machinist, to build a rope-ascending tool, today known as the Petzl Croll, that he had developed by adapting the [[Jumar]] to the specificity of pit caving. Following these developments, Fernand Petzl started in the 1970s a small caving equipment manufacturing company [[Petzl]].
==Standards==
* EN 567 <ref name=autogenerated1>{{cite web |url=http://www.petzl.com/files/all/technical-notice/Sport/B16_CROLL_B165000J.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-01-14 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100704235700/http://www.petzl.com/files/all/technical-notice/Sport/B16_CROLL_B165000J.pdf |archivedate=2010-07-04 |df= }}</ref> This standard allows the Croll to be used by [[Industrial Rope Access Trade Association|IRATA]] qualified technicians. * EN 12841 <ref name=autogenerated1 /> * CE 0197 <ref name=autogenerated1 />
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:Climbing equipment]] [[Category:Caving equipment]]

revision.comment: not an improvement. Undid revision 871145464 by [[Special:Contributions/103.231.44.22|103.231.44.22]] ([[User talk:103.231.44.22|talk]])
revision.text:
{{distinguish|Physics education}} {{redirect|Gym teacher|the 2008 movie|Gym Teacher: The Movie}} [[Image:Calhan Colorado High School Physical Education equipment by David Shankbone.jpg|240px|thumb|right|Physical education equipment in [[Calhan, Colorado|Calhan]], Colorado]] [[File:Pe class.jpg|thumb|Kids using a parachute during a PE lesson]] [[File:Teachers Physical Education (3307744445).jpg|thumb]] '''Physical education,''' also known as '''Phys Ed.''', '''PE''', '''gym''', or '''gym class''', and known in many [[Commonwealth of Nations|Commonwealth]] countries as '''physical training''' or '''PT''',<ref> [https://www.telegraph.co.uk/education/2459735/Physical-training-in-schools-should-be-compulsory-says-leading-head.html ''The Daily Telegraph'', 25 July 2008: "Physical training in schools should be compulsory, says leading head"] Linked 2014-04-09</ref> is an [[educational course]] related of maintaining the human body through physical exercises (i.e. [[calisthenics]]) (citation needed). It is taken during primary and [[secondary education]] and encourages [[psychomotor learning]] in a [[play (activity)|play]] or movement exploration setting to promote health.<ref>Anderson, D. (1989). ''The Discipline and the Profession.'' Foundations of Canadian Physical Education, Recreation, and Sports Studies. Dubuque, IA: Wm. C. Brown Publishers.</ref>
==Asia== In [[Singapore]], pupils from primary school through junior colleges are required to have two hours of PE every week, except during examination periods. Pupils may play games like [[soccer|football]], [[badminton]], [[captain ball]], and [[basketball]] during most sessions. Unorthodox sports such as [[fencing]], and [[skateboarding]] are occasionally played. In more prestigious secondary schools and in junior colleges, sports such as [[golf]], [[tennis]], [[marksmanship|shooting]], and [[squash (sport)|squash]] are played. (This paragraph needs to be cited. Where is this information from?)
An Biennial compulsory fitness exam, NAPFA, is conducted in every school to assess pupils' physical fitness in Singapore.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.asiaone.com/napfa-fitness-test-education-tool|title=Napfa: From fitness test to education tool|work=AsiaOne|access-date=2018-10-19}}</ref> This includes a series of fitness tests (pull-ups/inclined pull-ups for girls, standing broad jump, sit-ups, sit-and-reach and 1.6 km for primary [10- to 12-year-olds]/2.4 km for secondary and junior college levels [13- to 18-year-olds]). Students are graded by gold, silver, or bronze, or as fail. NAPFA for pre-enlistees serves as an indicator for an additional two months in the country's compulsory national service if they attain bronze or fail.
In [[Malaysia]], pupils from primary schools to secondary schools are expected to do two periods or one hour of PE throughout the year except a week before [[Test (assessment)|examinations]]. In most [[secondary schools]], games like badminton, [[sepak takraw]], [[association football|football]], [[netball]], basketball and tennis are available. Pupils may bring their own sports equipment to the school with the authorization of the teacher. (Again, citation needed for this paragraph. Where is this information from?)
In the [[Philippines]], PE is mandatory for all years, unless the school gives the option for a student to do the [[Leaving Certificate Vocational Programme]] instead for fifth and sixth year. Some schools have integrated martial arts training into their physical education curriculum.<ref>[http://www.visayandailystar.com/2008/September/27/sportnews1.htm ] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080930151303/http://www.visayandailystar.com/2008/September/27/sportnews1.htm |date=September 30, 2008 }}</ref><ref>[http://www.garimot.com/articles/index.html] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070523121915/http://www.garimot.com/articles/index.html |date=May 23, 2007 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.imafp.com/Chapters/IMAFP_commissions/IMAFP_mindanao.htm |title=Regional Commissions and Chapters International Modern Arnis Federation Philippines Mindanao Commission |publisher=Imafp.com |date= |accessdate=2010-11-07}}</ref><ref>[http://www.mindanaotimes.com.ph/story.php?id=22801 ] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090115150606/http://www.mindanaotimes.com.ph/story.php?id=22801 |date=January 15, 2009 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://showbizandstyle.inquirer.net/sim/sim/view/20081214-177923/Life-Lessons-from-Karate |title=Sunday Inquirer Magazine: Life Lessons from Karate |publisher=Showbizandstyle.inquirer.net |date=2008-12-14 |accessdate=2010-11-07 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120304154557/http://showbizandstyle.inquirer.net/sim/sim/view/20081214-177923/Life-Lessons-from-Karate |archivedate=2012-03-04 |df= }}</ref>
[[File:SMATrinitasORBenteng.JPG|thumb|Indonesian high school students playing the traditional game "Benteng"]] In [[Indonesia]], students ranging from [[kindergarten]] to [[high school]] have PE integrated with their curriculum. Kindergarten through grade 3 students have [[gymnastics]]. Starting from Grade 4, students are introduced to traditional martial arts [[Pencak Silat]] and some team games such as badminton, football, futsal, rounders, and basketball. Starting from [[junior high school]], games such as basketball, volleyball, cricket, tennis, badminton, kho kho, and kabaddi are played. Drills and physical training are taught.
In Bhutan, the inclusion of Health and Physical Education in the school curriculum was formally endorsed during the 7th CAPSD Board Meeting in 1997. A series of pilot tests were conducted in primary schools from 1998 to 1999. Since the pilot tests were very successful, HPE was introduced as a formal teaching subject in all the primary schools from the year 2000.
In 2007, a set of revised curriculum books, consisting of a curriculum framework and eight activity books, were developed for use from 2009 academic session.
==Australia== In [[Australia]], physical education was first made an important part of the curriculum in government primary and secondary schools in 1981. The policy was outlined in a Ministerial Statement to the Victorian Legislative Assembly by the Minister for Educational Services, [[Norman Lacy]] MP on 17 September.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://archive.org/stream/MinisterialStatementOnNewDirectionsInPhysicalEducation#page/n0/mode/1up |title=Ministerial Statement on New Directions in Physical Education |publisher=Archive.org |date= |accessdate=2015-08-13}}</ref>
==North America== {{multiple image | |width1 = 225 |image1 = 2011 Okemos High School Girls' Water Polo State Championship Team.jpg |width2 = 100 |image2 = TWU Gymnastics (Bars) Amy Winczura (5694030475).jpg |footer = ''Left:'' A U.S. high school girls' [[water polo]] team (with their male coaches in background) posing with their trophy. ''Right:'' A U.S. university girl practising a difficult [[gymnastics]] manoeuvre.}}
In the United States, the goal of physical education is to "develop physically literate individuals who have the knowledge, skills and confidence to enjoy a lifetime of healthful physical activity."<ref>{{Cite web|title = Shape America Home Page|url = http://www.shapeamerica.org|website = www.shapeamerica.org|accessdate = 2015-10-25}}</ref>
Zero Hour is a before-school physical education class first implemented by [[Naperville Central High School]]. In the state of [[Illinois]] this program is known as Learning Readiness P.E. (LRPE). It was based on research indicating that [[student]]s who are physically fit are more [[academics|academically]] alert and experience growth in [[brain cell]]s or enhancement in [[brain]] development. NCHS pairs a PE class that incorporates [[cardiovascular exercise]], [[core strength]] training, cross lateral movements, and [[literacy]] and [[math]] strategies with literacy and math classes that utilize movement to enhance [[learning]] and improve achievement.<ref>Enhancing P.E. in Illinois, http://iphionline.org/pdf/P.E._Case_Study_Naperville.pdf</ref>
In British Columbia, Canada, the government has stated in the grade one curriculum that students must participate in physical activity daily five times a week. The teacher is also responsible for planning Daily Physical Activity (DPA), which is thirty minutes of mild to moderate physical activity a day, not including curriculum physical education classes. The curriculum requires students in grade one to be knowledgeable about healthy living. For example, they must be able to describe benefits of regular exercise, identify healthy choices that require them to be more physically active, and describe the importance of choosing healthy food.<ref>BC curriculum package</ref>{{better citation needed|date=June 2018}} <!-- Not a strong source for this information. See actual curriculum documents for more reliable information regarding what students are learning. -->
Ontario, Canada has a similar procedure in place. On October 6, 2005 the Ontario Ministry of Education (OME) implemented a Daily Physical Activity policy in elementary schools, grades 1–8. It requires that all students in grades 1 to 8, including those with special needs, be provided with opportunities to participate in a minimum of twenty minutes of sustained moderate to vigorous physical activity each school day during instructional time.<ref>[http://www.edu.gov.on.ca/eng/teachers/dpa1-3.pdf] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061212025619/http://www.edu.gov.on.ca/eng/teachers/dpa1-3.pdf |date=December 12, 2006 }}</ref> There are many factors that contribute to the ease of implementing and sustaining a quality program, including the involvement of the administration, parents, and community. However, it ultimately comes down to the willingness of the physical education teacher(s) to do their best no matter the situation <ref>The Importance of Physical Education https://www.supportrealteachers.org/the-importance-of-quality-physical-education.html?gclid=Cj0KCQjwiJncBRC1ARIsAOvG-a5DFCcyvtwvTO6TWrGWTlSx7w1mmTqLbz4jFcQRk2MNf73vNIItQS8aAvUSEALw_wcB</ref>
==Europe== [[Image:JJS Karate Kids.jpg|thumb|Some countries include [[martial arts]] training in school as part of Physical Education class. These [[Filipino people|Filipino]] children are doing [[karate]].]]
In [[Portugal]], pupils from primary school can optionally join PE as an extra-curricular activity. From middle school to secondary school, pupils must participate in PE classes for two hours per week.{{citation needed|date=November 2012}}
[[Scotland]] has is a government supported requirement of a minimum of two hours of quality PE in primary and two periods (50 minutes each) in secondary S1 to S4. Recent funding has ensured most local authorities have employed PE lead officers to support the requirement. In fifth and sixth year, PE is voluntary in that personalisation and choice must be considered.{{Citation needed|date=April 2010}}
In [[England]], pupils are expected to do two hours of PE a week in year 7, 8 and 9 and at least one in year 10 and 11.<ref>{{cite web|title=National curriculum in England: physical education programmes of study|url=https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/national-curriculum-in-england-physical-education-programmes-of-study/national-curriculum-in-england-physical-education-programmes-of-study|website=GOV.UK|publisher=Department for Education|accessdate=24 November 2016}} [[File:UKOpenGovernmentLicence.svg|50px]] This content is available under the [http://www.nationalarchives.gov.uk/doc/open-government-licence/version/3/ Open Government Licence v3.0]. © Crown copyright.</ref>
In [[Wales]], pupils are expected to do two hours of PE a week.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://sport.wales/media/351730/sports_update_59-e.pdf|title=PE Provision in Secondary Schools |accessdate=28 July 2016|work=Sports Council Wales}}</ref>
In [[Poland]], pupils are expected to do at least three hours of PE a week during primary and secondary education.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://isip.sejm.gov.pl/DetailsServlet?id=WDU20020150142|title=Dz.U. 2002 nr 15 poz. 142. Rozporządzenie Ministra Edukacji Narodowej i Sportu z dnia 12 lutego 2002 r. w sprawie ramowych planów nauczania w szkołach publicznych.|publisher=Internetowy System Aktów Prawnych|accessdate=31 October 2010}}</ref> Universities must also organise at least 60 hours of physical education classes at undergraduate courses.<ref>{{cite web|title=Standardy kształcenia dla poszczególnych kierunków studiów i poziomów kształcenia|url=http://www.bip.nauka.gov.pl/bipmein/index.jsp?place=Lead07&news_cat_id=117&news_id=982&layout=1&page=text|publisher=Biuletyn Informacj Publicznej|accessdate=31 October 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101120214522/http://www.bip.nauka.gov.pl/bipmein/index.jsp?place=Lead07&news_cat_id=117&news_id=982&layout=1&page=text|archivedate=20 November 2010|df=}}</ref>
In [[Sweden]] it differs from municipality to municipality but generally, year 0 to 2 has 55 minutes PE a week. Year 3 to 6 has 110 minutes a week and year 7-9 has 220 minutes. In upper secondary school, all national programs have an obligatory course, Idrott och hälsa 1, containing 100 points of PE, which corresponds to 90-100 hours of PE during the course. (One point should be one hour, but due to holidays this isn't true.) The schools can spend these hours as they like during the three years students attend. Most schools put this course during the first year and offer the follow-up course, Idrott och hälsa 2, which also contains 100 points.{{Citation needed|date=June 2018}}
In Ireland, you are expected to do 2 Classes worth of P.E.(80 Minutes)This also includes Shower and Changing Times, so averagely 60-65 minutes outside. <!-- References needed for this paragraph. -->
==Trends== {{refimprove|date=March 2013}} [[File:Corta-Mato Escolar 2008.jpg|thumb|left|Young [[Portugal|Portuguese]] children participating in a school race]] Physical education [[fad|trends]] have developed recently{{when|date=March 2014}} to incorporate a greater variety of activities besides typical [[sports]]. Introducing students to activities like [[bowling]], [[walking]]/[[hiking]], or [[frisbee]] at an early age can help them develop good activity habits that will continue into adulthood.
Some [[teacher]]s have begun to incorporate stress-reduction techniques such as [[yoga]], deep breathing and [[tai chi]]. Tai chi, an ancient martial arts form focused on slow meditative movements, is a relaxation activity with many benefits. Studies have shown that it enhances muscular strength and endurance, as well as cardiovascular endurance. It also provides psychological benefits such as improving general mental health, concentration, awareness and positive mood.<ref>{{cite web|title=Tai Chi for Mental Health {{!}} Psych Central News|url=http://psychcentral.com/news/2010/05/24/tai-chi-for-mental-health/14015.html|website=Psych Central News|date=24 May 2010}}</ref> It can be taught to any age student with little or no equipment, making it ideal for mixed ability and age classes. Tai chi can easily be incorporated into a holistic learning body and mind unit.<ref>Lu C. (2007 {{full citation needed|date=February 2017}})</ref>
Teaching non-traditional sports may also provide motivation for students to increase their activity, and can help them learn about different cultures. For example, while learning about [[lacrosse]] in the Southwestern United States, students might also learn about the Native American cultures of the Northeastern United States and Eastern Canada, where the sport originated. Teaching non-traditional (or non-native) sports provides an opportunity to integrate academic concepts from other subjects as well, which may now be required of many PE teachers.{{citation needed|date=March 2013}}
PE is very important to students' health and overall well-being. The [[Centers for Disease Control and Prevention]] stated that over the past three years{{when|date=June 2018}} obesity in children (ages 2–5) and adolescents (ages 12–19) has doubled because of diet and lack of activity. Since the 1970s the number of children who are obese has tripled.<ref>The Importance of Physical Education. (n.d.). Retrieved April 1, 2016, from http://www.veanea.org/home/1000.htm</ref> [[File:Jf;fhjk;sfdbkdfl'b.jpg|thumbnail]]
SHAPE America's National Standards & Grade-Level Outcomes for K-12 Physical Education define what a student should know and be able to do as result of an effective physical education program.<ref>http://www.shapeamerica.org/standards/pe/</ref>
Another trend is the incorporation of [[health]] and [[nutrition]] into the physical education curriculum. The [[Child Nutrition and WIC Reauthorization Act of 2004]] required that all school districts with a federally-funded school meal program develop wellness policies that address nutrition and physical activity.<ref>Pangrazi, Robert (2007) "Dynamic Physical Education for Elementary School Children" 15th ed.</ref> While teaching students sports and movement skills, PE teachers are now incorporating short health and nutrition lessons into the curriculum. This is more prevalent at the elementary school level, where students do not have a specific Health class. Recently most elementary schools have specific health classes for students as well as physical education class. Due to the recent outbreaks of diseases such as swine flu, school districts are making it mandatory for students to learn about practicing good hygiene along with other health topics.{{citation needed|date=June 2018}}
Today many states require Physical Education teachers to be certified to teach Health courses. Many colleges and universities offer both Physical Education and Health as one certification. This push towards health education is beginning at the intermediate level, including lessons on bullying, self-esteem and stress and anger management.{{citation needed|date=June 2018}}
Research has shown that there is a positive correlation between brain development and exercising.<ref>{{cite news|last=REYNOLDS|first=GRETCHEN|title=Phys Ed: Can Exercise Make Kids Smarter?|url=http://well.blogs.nytimes.com/2010/09/15/phys-ed-can-exercise-make-kids-smarter/|accessdate=18 April 2013|newspaper=The New York Times}}</ref>
Incorporating local indigenous knowledge into physical education can lead to many meaningful experiences and a way of learning about other cultures. For example, by incorporating traditional knowledge from varying indigenous groups from across Canada, students can be exposed to many concepts such as holistic learning and the medicine wheel. A unit could be focused on connecting to a place or feeling while outdoors, participating in traditional games, or outdoor environmental education. These types of lesson can easily be integrated into other parts of the curriculum and give Aboriginal students a chance to incorporate their culture in the local school community.<ref>Lowen, G {{full citation needed|date=February 2017}}</ref>
Studies have been done in how physical education can help improve academic achievement. In a 2007 article, researchers found a profound gain in English Arts [[standardized testing]] test scores among students who had 56 hours of physical education in a year, compared to those who had 28 hours of physical education a year.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Tremarche|first1=Pamela V.|last2=Robinson|first2=Ellyn M.|last3=Graham|first3=Louise B.|title=Physical Education and Its Effect on Elementary Testing Results|journal=Physical Educator|date=2007|volume=64|issue=2 |pages=58–64}}</ref>
In [[Brazil]], the physical education curriculum is designed to allow school pupils a full range of modern opportunities, including sports. [[Martial arts]] classes, like [[wrestling]] in the United States, and [[Pencak Silat]] in France, [[Indonesia]], and [[Malaysia]], teach children [[self-defense]] and to feel good about themselves. The physical education curriculum is designed to allow students to experience at least a minimum exposure to the following categories of activities: [[aquatic sports|aquatics]], conditioning activities, [[gymnastics]], individual/dual sports, [[team sports]], rhythms, and [[dance]].
In these areas, a planned sequence of learning experiences is designed to support a progression of student development. This allows kids through 6th grade to be introduced to sports, fitness, and teamwork in order to be better prepared for the middle and high school age. In 1975, the [[United States House of Representatives]] voted to require school physical education classes include [[coeducation|both genders]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://tvnews.vanderbilt.edu/program.pl?ID=483834 |title=Physical Education – Jul 18, 1975 – NBC – TV news: Vanderbilt Television News Archive |publisher=Tvnews.vanderbilt.edu |date=1975-07-18 |accessdate=2015-08-13}}</ref> Some high school and some middle school PE classes are single-sex. <!-- This makes no sense as written. Can someone clarify?) Requiring individuals to participate in physical education activities, such as [[dodge ball]], [[flag football]], and other competitive sports remains a controversial subject because of the social impact these have cases physical education programs have been cut.--><!-- A lot of research shows the benefits of physical education however there can also be a lot of negative experiences students deal with regarding physical education. --><!-- A section detailing possible negative experiences students may face during physical education would be beneficial -->
==Technology use in physical education==
New technology in education is playing a big role in classes. One of the most affordable and effective tools is a simple video recorder. With this, students can see the mistakes they're making in things such as a throwing motion or swinging form.<ref name="autogenerated1">Wang, L., Myers, D., & Yanes, M. (2010). Creating student-centered learning experience through the assistance of high-end technology in physical education. Journal of Instructional Psychology, 37(4), 352–356.</ref> Studies show that students find this more effective than having someone try to explain what they are doing wrong, and then trying to correct it.<ref name="autogenerated1"/> Educators may use technologies such as [[pedometer]]s and [[heart rate monitor]]s to make step and heart rate goals for students.<ref>Woods, M., Karp, G., Goc, H., & Perlman, D. (2008). Physical educators' usage. Physical Educator, 65(2), 82–99</ref>
Other technologies that can be used in a Physical Education setting include [[video projector]]s, [[GPS]] and games and gaming systems such as [[Kinect]], [[Wii]] Fit and ''[[Dance Dance Revolution]]''. Projectors can show students proper form or how to play certain games. [[GPS]] systems can be used to get students active in an outdoor setting, and active exergames{{clarify|date=October 2014}} can be used by teachers to show students a good way to stay fit in and out of the classroom setting.<ref>Grimes, G. (2011, November 21). Interview by M Massey [Personal Interview].</ref>
Another type of technology that is commonly used in Physical Education is the pedometer. This does not necessarily track how far a person is going, but lets them know the number of steps they are taking.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.humankinetics.com/excerpts/excerpts/using-pedometers-to-assess-physical-activity-participation-levels |title=Using pedometers to assess physical activity participation levels |publisher=Humankinetics.com |date=2010-04-01 |accessdate=2015-08-13}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pecentral.org/lessonideas/pedometer/pedometerlessonndex.html |title=PEC: Pedometer Lesson Activities |publisher=Pecentral.org |date= |accessdate=2015-08-13}}</ref>
==See also== *[[Sports day]] *[[Recreation]] *[[Lack of physical education]]
