{{double image|right|Elisabetta Canalis 0380.jpg|240|The Mankini.jpg|320|[[Elisabetta Canalis]] in a pretzel swimsuit, and a mankini made famous by the film ''[[Borat]]''.}} The '''sling swimsuit''' is a [[one-piece swimsuit]] which is supported by fabric at the neck. In practice, sling swimsuits provide as little, or even less, coverage (or as much exposure) as a [[bikini]]. [[Monokini]] types also exist. The sling swimsuit is also known by a variety of names including "suspender bikini", "sling bikini", "suspender thong", "slingshot swimsuit" or just "slingshot". It is so named because of its resemblance to the Y-shape frame of a [[slingshot]]. It is sometimes listed as a [[Bikini variants|bikini variant]]. When designed for or worn by a man, it is often called a "mankini".
==Design== Usually, a sling swimsuit comprises a bikini bottom of any style, with side straps extending upwards to cover the breasts, then going over the shoulders and behind the neck or extending down the back. The sling swimsuit leaves the sides of the torso uncovered, while covering the nipples and pubic area. Behind the neck, the straps may join and reach down the back to the buttocks [[thong (garment)|thong]] or string style.<ref name=JenPa>Jenny Pate, [http://www.articledashboard.com/Article/History-of-Swimsuits/461234 History of the swimsuit] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080907051823/http://www.articledashboard.com/Article/History-of-Swimsuits/461234 |date=2008-09-07 }}, Article Dashboard</ref>
The variation of sling swimsuits is a '''pretzel swimsuit''', which has the straps behind the neck and another set of straps around the midriff, instead of straps down the back.<ref name=JenPa/> Even more "risqué" [[Europe]]an designs include the bodyform-suspender (by German manufacturer Nixxxe)<ref>[https://archive.is/20130411114530/http://www.nixxxe.com/shop.php?action=details&artnr=1015&lang=en NIXXXE.com - Bodyform-Suspender]</ref> and other open bust and/or crotchless variants such as the "peekaboo" slingshot (by Spanish manufacturer the-Bikinis)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.the-bikinis.com/PeekaBoo-SlingShot/vmchk.html|title=PeekaBoo SlingShot|work=the-bikinis.com|accessdate=29 March 2015}}</ref> and "ouvert" sling bikini (by German manufacturer Tangaland).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tangaland24.de/products/en/extrem-Bikini/Ouvert-Sling-Bikini.html|title=String Tanga transparent swimsuits|author=Gerorge G.|work=micro Bikini Onlinestore Tangaland|accessdate=29 March 2015}}</ref>
A sling swimsuit worn by men is often called a '''mankini'''. It was popularized by [[Sacha Baron Cohen]], who donned one in the film ''[[Borat]]''. The buzz around the film started building during the [[Cannes Film Festival]] in May 2006, when Baron Cohen posed in character on the beach in a fluorescent green mankini, alongside four models.<ref>Josh Friedman & Lorenza Munoz, "[https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/latimes/access/1150656071.html?dids=1150656071:1150656071&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&date=Oct+25%2C+2006&author=Josh+Friedman+and+Lorenza+Munoz&pub=Los+Angeles+Times&desc=Fox+scales+back+%60Borat%27+movie%27s+opening%3B+The+comedy+will+first+be+shown+in+800+theaters%2C+down+from+2%2C000%2C+amid+a+lack+of+awareness.&pqatl=google Fox scales back `Borat' movie's opening; The comedy will first be shown in 800 theaters, down from 2,000, amid a lack of awareness]", ''The Los Angeles Times'', page C1, 2006-10-25</ref> A [[garden gnome]] in the 2011 film ''[[Gnomeo and Juliet]]'' was also shown wearing a mankini, which gets referred to as a Borat-Mankini by newspapers.<ref> [http://www.chron.com/disp/story.mpl/ent/movies/mobile/7422124.html Gnomeo & Juliet – Houston Chronicle]. Chron.com (2011-02-10). Retrieved on 2011-12-03.</ref>
==History== Corresponding to the introduction of [[Lycra]] into swimwear, sling swimsuits emerged in the early 1990s. They are more popular on some beaches of Europe, including [[Saint-Tropez]], [[Marbella]], [[Mykonos]] and [[Ibiza]].<ref>[http://swimsuits.lovetoknow.com/Slingshot_Suspender_Bikini Slingshot Suspender Bikinis: A History] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120730105128/http://swimsuits.lovetoknow.com/Slingshot_Suspender_Bikini |date=2012-07-30 }}, Love to know swimsuits, Glam Publisher Network</ref> Suspender-like straps running between the breasts and around the neck that held the suit up were introduced in the mainstream in 1994. News reports said that within a week of putting the suit on their racks, [[New York City|New York]]'s major stores had sold 150. By season's end, the tally sold was over 3000, at a cost of $24 a suit.<ref>Fashion Correspondent, "[http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=MH&s_site=miami&p_multi=MH&p_theme=realcities&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=0EB4D23272FD283B&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&s_trackval=GooglePM Itsy bitsy teenie weenie... trivia think swimsuits. If two-pieces and t-backs are all that come to mind... think again]", ''Miami Herald'', page 1G, 1995-07-15</ref>
==References== {{Commonscat|Mankini|Sling swimsuit}} {{reflist}}

The stadium is able to hold 9,500 spectators. It was used as a venue for the [[2013 IRB Junior World Championship]], which was won by England. {{Infobox non Test cricket team | name = Switzerland | image = Cricket Switzerland Logo V1.jpg | image_size = 150px | caption = | nickname = | association = Cricket Switzerland | icc_status = Affiliate | icc_member_year = 1985–2012 | icc_region = [[ICC Europe|Europe]] | WCL_division = n/a (regional tournaments) | coach = Chris Lodge | captain = [https://www.cricketswitzerland.ch/seniors/player-profiles/matthew-martin/ Matthew Martin] | first_match = {{flagicon|Switzerland}} '''Switzerland''' v. {{cr-rt|Greece}}
([[Castel, Guernsey]]; 21 May 1990) | asofdate = 13 September 2015 }} The '''Switzerland national cricket team''' represents the country of [[Switzerland]] (also known as the [[Swiss Confederation]]) in [[international cricket]]. ==History== Cricket has been played in Switzerland since at least 1817.{{cite web|url=http://www.cricketswitzerland.ch/about-1/ |title=About - Cricket Switzerland |publisher=Cricketswitzerland.ch |date= |accessdate=2015-09-13}} The association (renamed to Cricket Switzerland{{cite web|url=http://www.cricketswitzerland.ch |title=Cricket Switzerland - Cricket Switzerland |publisher=Cricketswitzerland.ch |date= |accessdate=2015-09-13}} in 2014), became an affiliate member of the [[International Cricket Council]] in 1985.{{cite web|url=http://www.cricketarchive.co.uk/Archive/Countries/84.html |title=The Home of CricketArchive |publisher=Cricketarchive.co.uk |date=2015-08-06 |accessdate=2015-09-13}} They hosted the first tournament for European affiliate members in [[Zuoz]] in 1997, the European Nations Cup, where they came fifth in the seven team tournament. They then played in the successor tournament, the [[European Cricket Council]] Trophy in 1999, 2001 and 2003, their best result coming in 1999 when they reached the semi-finals. They then played in the European Representative Championship in [[Slovenia]] in 2004, where they came third in the six team tournament. The national played in Division Four of the [[European Cricket Championship|European Championship]] in 2009 having been promoted from Division Five, playing [[Austria national cricket team|Austria]], [[Cyprus national cricket team|Cyprus]], [[Finland national cricket team|Finland]], [[Luxembourg national cricket team|Luxembourg]] and [[Slovenia national cricket team|Slovenia]]. Switzerland was ranked to participate in ICC European Division II, Belgium 2011. Unfortunately internal differences prevented Switzerland from participating in the tournament and hence was demoted to Division III. These internal differences resulted from two rival governing bodies attempting to govern cricket in Switzerland, neither of which are members of the [[Swiss Olympic Association]], which led to Switzerland breaching membership regulations of the [[International Cricket Council]]. This led to Switzerland's affiliate membership being removed.{{cite web|url=http://www.icc-cricket.com/newsdetails.php?newsId=20708_1340883300|title=ICC Annual Conference in Kuala Lumpur|publisher=[[International Cricket Council]]|accessdate=9 July 2012}} There are currently 21 clubs playing in Switzerland.{{cite web|url=http://www.cricketswitzerland.ch/about-1/clubs-affiliates/ |title=Clubs & Affiliates - Cricket Switzerland |publisher=Cricketswitzerland.ch |date= |accessdate=2015-09-13}} ==Current squad== The following lists the Swiss squad from which players were selected to represent Switzerland since the International Twenty20 series against [http://www.cricketswitzerland.ch/news/2013/2013-austria-report/ Austria] on 22 & 23 June 2013 and against [http://www.cricketswitzerland.ch/news/2013/2013-sussex-report/ University of Sussex Cricket Club] from 3-5 July 2013. *Afzaal Sikander[http://www.cricketswitzerland.ch/seniors/player-profiles/afzaal-sikander/] *Asvin {{Good article}} {{Use British English|date=July 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2014}} {{Infobox University Boat Race | name= 12th Boat Race | winner = Oxford | margin = 7 lengths | winning_time= 25 minutes 29 seconds | overall = 7–5 | umpire =[[Charles Jasper Selwyn|C. J. Selwyn]] | date= {{Start date|1854|4|8|df=y}} | prevseason= [[The Boat Race 1852|1852]] | nextseason= [[The Boat Race 1856|1856]] }} The '''12th Boat Race''' took place on the [[River Thames]] on 8 April 1854. Typically held annually, the event is a [[Rowing (sport)#Side by side|side-by-side rowing]] race between crews from the Universities of [[University of Oxford|Oxford]] and [[University of Cambridge|Cambridge]]. The race was won by Oxford who triumphed over Cambridge by seven lengths. ==Background== [[Image:Selwyns.jpg|thumb|right|upright|Sir Charles Jasper Selwyn ''(standing)'' was the umpire for the fifth time.MacMichael, p. 213]] [[The Boat Race]] is a [[Rowing (sport)#Side by side|side-by-side rowing]] competition between the [[University of Oxford]] (sometimes referred to as the "Dark Blues"){{Cite web | url = https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2003/apr/06/theobserver | work = [[The Observer]] | title = Dark Blues aim to punch above their weight | date = 6 April 2003 | accessdate = 1 September 2014 }} and the [[University of Cambridge]] (sometimes referred to as the "Light Blues"). The race was first held in 1829, and since 1845 has taken place on the {{convert|4.2|mi|km|adj=on}} [[The Championship Course|Championship Course]] on the [[River Thames]] in southwest London.{{Cite web | url = https://www.telegraph.co.uk/travel/destinations/europe/uk/london/10719622/University-Boat-Race-2014-spectators-guide.html | work = [[The Daily Telegraph]] | accessdate = 3 June 2014 | date = 25 March 2014 |title = University Boat Race 2014: spectators' guide | first = Oliver |last =Smith}}{{Cite web | url = http://theboatraces.org/the-course | title = The Course| accessdate = 7 November 2014 | publisher = The Boat Race Company Limited}} Oxford went into the race as reigning champions, having defeated Cambridge by nine lengths in the [[The Boat Race 1852|previous race]]. Cambridge led overall with seven wins to Oxford's four.{{Cite web | url = http://theboatraces.org/results| publisher= The Boat Race Company Limited | title = Boat Race – Results| accessdate = 7 November 2014}} There was no Boat Race in 1853 as the [[Henley Royal Regatta]] was scheduled for the same time as that proposed by Cambridge in their challenge to Oxford. The universities did however race each other that year, in the [[Grand Challenge Cup]], which was won by Oxford.MacMichael, pp. 197–202 On 11 February 1854, a challenge was sent to Oxford by the former Light Blue [[Coxswain|cox]] [[Thomas Selby Egan]], who had assumed temporary captaincy of [[Cambridge University Boat Club]], despite having coached the Dark Blues to victory in the 1852 race.MacMichael, p. 204{{Cite book | title = Rowing in England: A Social History : the Amateur Debate | first = Eric |last = Halladay | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=9Ee8AAAAIAAJ&pg=PA46&dq=%22Egan%22+Oxford+coach&hl=en&sa=X&ei=_c9cVPKpLoevPILMgKAL&ved=0CDAQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=%22Egan%22%20Oxford%20coach&f=false | pages = 45–46 | publisher = [[Manchester University Press]] | date = 18 October 1990 | isbn = 978-0-7190260-5-8}} Although Oxford arrived at Putney as favourites to win the race, Cambridge's style was enough to force the odds to evens. However, in a practice race, the Dark Blues defeated a [[Waterman (occupation)|watermen]] scratch crew easily and restored their position as pre-race favourites.Drinkwater, p. 40 Both crews rowed in {{convert|65|ft|m|adj=on}} long boats manufactured by Searle.MacMichael, p. 214 The umpire for the race was [[Charles Jasper Selwyn]] and the starter was Edward Searle.Burnell p. 49 ==Crews== The Oxford crew weighed an average of 11 [[Stone (unit)|st]] 1 [[Pound (mass)|lb]] (70.1 kg), {{convert|5.75|lb|kg|1}} per rower more than their opponents. Cambridge saw one rower return from the 1852 race in F. Johnson, while Oxford's crew contained two former [[Blue (university sport)|Blues]] in Nind and the [[Oxford University Boat Club]] president Olliver Meade King. {| class=wikitable |- ! rowspan="2" |Seat ! colspan="3" |Cambridge
[[File:University of Cambridge coat of arms.svg|30px]] ! colspan="3" |Oxford
[[File:Oxford-University-Circlet.svg|30px]] |- | Name | College | Weight | Name | College | Weight |- | [[Bow (rowing)|Bow]] || R. C. Galton || [[Trinity College, Cambridge|1st Trinity]] || 9 st 10 lb || [[Walter Francis Short|W. F. Short]] || [[New College, Oxford|New College]] || 10 st 5 lb |- | 2 || Spencer Nairne || [[Emmanuel College, Cambridge|Emmanuel]] || 10 st 2 lb || Alfred Hooke || [[Worcester College, Oxford|Worcester]] || 11 st 0 lb |- | 3 || J. Coope Davis || [[Trinity College, Cambridge|3rd Trinity]] || 11 st 1 lb || W. Pinckney || [[Exeter College, Oxford|Exeter]] || 11 st 2 lb |- | 4 || [[Stair Agnew|S. Agnew]] || [[Trinity College, Cambridge|1st Trinity]] || 10 st 12 lb || T. H. Blundell || [[Christ Church, Oxford|Christ Church]] || 11 st 8 lb |- | 5 || E. Courage || [[Trinity College, Cambridge|1st Trinity]] || 11 st 13 lb || Edward Hooper || [[Pembroke College, Oxford|Pembroke]] || 11 st 5 lb |- | 6 || F. W. Johnson || [[Trinity College, Cambridge|3rd Trinity]] || 10 st 13 lb || [[Philip Henry Nind|P. H. Nind]] || [[Christ Church, Oxford|Christ Church]] || 10 st 12 lb |- | 7 || H. Blake || [[Corpus Christi College, Cambridge|Corpus Christi]] || 11 st 1 lb || G. L. Mellish || [[Exeter College, Oxford|Exeter]] || 11 st 2 lb |- | [[Stroke (rowing)|Stroke]] || J. Wright || [[St John's College, Cambridge|St John's]] || 10 st 2 lb || W. Olliver Meade King (P) || [[Pembroke College, Oxford|Pembroke]] || 11 st 8 lb |- | [[Coxswain (rowing)|Cox]] || C. T. Smith || [[Gonville and Caius College, Cambridge|Gonville and Caius]] || 9 st 12 lb || T. H. Marshall || [[Exeter College, Oxford|Exeter]] || 10 st 3 lb |- !colspan="7"|Source:MacMichael, p. 211
(P) – boat club president |} ==Race== [[File:University Boat Race Thames map.svg|right|thumb|[[The Championship Course]] along which the Boat Race is competed]] Oxford were pre-race favourites.MacMichael, p. 209 They won the toss and elected to start from the Middlesex station, handing Cambridge the Surrey side of the river. The race commenced at 10.40am, with Oxford pulling away from the start. The Dark Blues were clear of Cambridge by the time the crews reached the Crab Tree. By [[Hammersmith Bridge]] both coxes were forced to take evasive action as a result of a barge blocking their route.MacMichael, p. 212 With a lead of two lengths after the bridge, Oxford continued to increase their lead, eventually passing the flag-boat with a seven-length advantage in a time of 25 minutes 29 seconds. It was their third consecutive victory and took the overall record to 7–5 in Cambridge's favour. In a speech in the evening's celebrations, Charles Selwyn, who had umpired this and the previous four Boat Races, declared that he was "no longer young and active enough" to continue to act in the capacity of umpire; he would be replaced in 1856 by W. G. Rich, the former [[Cambridge University Boat Club]] president who had rowed in both the [[The Boat Race 1849 (March)|March]] and [[The Boat Race 1849 (December)|December races]] of 1849.MacMichael, pp. 150, 160 ==References== '''Notes''' {{reflist|30em}} '''Bibliography''' *{{Cite book | title = One Hundred and Fifty Years of the Oxford and Cambridge Boat Race | first = Richard | last = Burnell | authorlink = Dickie Burnell | year=1979| isbn= 978-0-9500638-7-4 | publisher = Precision Press}} *{{Cite book | title = The University Boat Race – Official Centenary History | first = G. C. |last = Drinkwater | first2= T. R. B. |last2=Sanders |publisher = Cassell & Company, Ltd.| year = 1929}} *{{Cite book | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=uJ8CAAAAYAAJ&dq=%22boat%20race%22%20oxford%20cambridge&pg=PA37| title = The Oxford and Cambridge Boat Races: From A.D. 1829 to 1869| first = William Fisher | last = MacMichael | publisher = Deighton | date = 1870}} ==External links== * [http://theboatraces.org/ Official website] {{The Boat Race}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Boat Race 1854)}} [[Category:1854 in sports]] [[Category:The Boat Race]] [[Category:April 1854 sports events]]

{{Infobox bandy team | team = Universal Saratov | logo = Universal Saratov logo.jpg | founded = {{start date and age|1953}} | folded = | league = | division = | arena = [[Dynamo Stadium (Saratov)|Dynamo Stadium]] | city = [[Saratov]], Russia | coach = | website = <!-- Home --> |pattern_he1 = |pattern_la1 = |pattern_b1 = |pattern_ra1 = |pattern_sh1 = |pattern_so1 = |leftarm1 = |body1 = |rightarm1 = |shorts1 = <!-- Away --> |pattern_he2 = |pattern_la2 = |pattern_b2 = |pattern_ra2 = |pattern_sh2 = |pattern_so2 = |leftarm2 = |body2 = |rightarm2 = |shorts2 = }} '''Universal Saratov''' ({{lang-ru|Универсал Саратов}}) is a [[bandy]] club in [[Saratov]], Russia. The club was founded in 1953 and is playing in the [[Russian Bandy Supreme League]], the second tier of Russian bandy.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rusbandy.ru/club/23/|publisher= rusbandy.ru|title= «Универсал» Саратов|language= Russian|accessdate= 20 July 2015}}</ref> The home games are played at [[Stadium Dynamo, Saratov|Stadium Dynamo]].<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.rusbandy.ru/stadium/31/|publisher= rusbandy.ru|title= Стадион «Динамо», Саратов|language= Russian|accessdate= 20 July 2015}}</ref> The building of an indoor arena is being considered.<ref>[https://translate.google.co.uk/translate?hl=en&sl=ru&tl=en&u=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.rusbandy.ru%2Fnews%2F9032%2F&sandbox=1 rusbandy.ru]</ref> The club colours are black and white.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://bandysaratov.ucoz.ru/|publisher= «Универсал» Саратов |title= «Универсал» Саратов |language= Russian |accessdate= 20 July 2015}}</ref>
Team picture: [http://www.rusbandy.ru/pix/21696.jpeg]
==External links== [http://bandysaratov.ucoz.ru/ Official homepage]

{{Infobox football club | clubname = WR Bentalha | image = Wr bentalha.png | fullname = Widad Riadhi de Bentalha | nickname = El safra | founded = [[1979 in association football|1979]]
(as ''Widad Riadhi de Bentalha'') | ground = [[Stade Aït El Hocine (Baraki)]] | capacity = 5,000 | chrtitle = President | chairman = [[Djilali Dahmani]] | mgrtitle = Head Coach | manager = [[Hocine Yahia]] | league = [[Championnat National de Football Amateur]] | season = [[2009-10 Algerian Championnat National 2|2009–10]] | position = Championnat National 2, '''12th''' | current = 2010–11 WR Bentalha season | pattern_la1 = | pattern_b1 = | pattern_ra1 = | leftarm1 = 000000 | body1 = FFFF00 | rightarm1 = FFFFFF | shorts1 = | socks1 = FFFF00 | pattern_la2 = | pattern_b2 = | pattern_ra2 = | leftarm2 = FFFFFF | body2 = FFFFFF | rightarm2 = FFFFFF | shorts2 = | socks2 = FFFF00 }} '''Widad Riadhi de Bentalha''' (commonly known as '''WR Bentalha''' or simply '''El safra''' is an Algerian [[Algerian Championnat National 2|Championnat National 2]] football club based in [[Bentalha]]. The club was founded in 1979.{{Cite web |url=http://www.lnf.dz/wrb.html |title=Ligue Nationale de Football |access-date=2010-12-23 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100909231633/http://www.lnf.dz/wrb.html |archive-date=2010-09-09 |dead-url=yes |df= }} ==History== The club was demoted from the second division for the newly created 2010–11 season of the [[Championnat National de Football Amateur]] due to the professionalisation of the first two divisions in [[Algeria]].[http://www.dzfoot.com/news-7244/amateurs-les-2-groupes-du-championnat-national/ Amateurs : Les 2 groupes du Championnat national – Football algérien] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131029202258/http://www.dzfoot.com/news-7244/amateurs-les-2-groupes-du-championnat-national/ |date=October 29, 2013 }} ==Current squad (2010–2011)== ''As of July 5, 2010:'' {{Fs start}} {{Fs player|no=5|nat=ALG|name=[[Salah Mohamed Samadi]]|pos=GK}} {{Fs player|no=6|nat=ALG|name=[[Rabah Deghmani]]|pos=DF}} {{Fs player|no=8|nat=ALG|name=[[Ishak Ali Moussa]]|pos=FW}} {{Fs end}} ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==External links== *[http://www.dzfoot.com/clubs/clubs.php?club_id=210/ WR Bentalha profile] at [http://www.dzfoot.com/ dzfoot.com] *[https://int.soccerway.com/teams/algeria/wr-bentalha/ WR Bentalha profile] at [https://int.soccerway.com/ soccerway.com] {{Championnat National de Football Amateur Groupe Centre-Ouest}} {{Football in Algeria}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Bentalha, WR}} [[Category:Football clubs in Algeria]] [[Category:Algiers Province]] [[Category:Association football clubs established in 1979]] [[Category:1979 establishments in Algeria]] {{Algeria-footyclub-stub}}

{{Infobox stadium | stadium_name = West Palm Beach
Municipal Stadium | nickname = Municipal Stadium | image = | fullname = West Palm Beach
Municipal Stadium | location = 755 [[Hank Aaron]] Drive
[[West Palm Beach, Florida]] | coordinates = {{coord|26.7215|-80.0795|type:landmark|display=inline,title}} | broke_ground = | built = 1962 | opened = March 9, 1963 | renovated = | expanded = | closed = 1997 | demolished = 2002 | owner = | operator = | surface = Natural grass | construction_cost = [[United States dollar|$]]1.0 million | architect = | structural engineer = | services engineer = | general_contractor= | project_manager = | main_contractors = | former_names = | tenants = [[Atlanta Braves|Milwaukee / Atlanta Braves]] ([[Major League Baseball|MLB]])
(spring training: 1963–1997)
[[Montreal Expos]] ([[Major League Baseball|MLB]])
(spring training: 1969–1972 & 1981–1997)
[[West Palm Beach Expos]] ([[Florida State League|FSL]]) (1969–1997)
{{nowrap|[[West Palm Beach Tropics]] ([[Senior Professional Baseball Association|SPBA]]) (1989–1990)}} | seating_capacity = 4,200 (1963)
5,000 (1986) | dimensions = }} '''West Palm Beach Municipal Stadium''', referred to as "Municipal Stadium," is a former [[baseball park]] in the [[Southeastern United States|southeastern]] [[United States]], in [[West Palm Beach, Florida]]. Located at 755 Hank Aaron Drive, it was the long-time [[spring training]] home for the [[Atlanta Braves|Milwaukee and Atlanta Braves]] and [[Montreal Expos]]. The Braves played spring training games at the stadium from [[1963 Milwaukee Braves season|1963]] to [[1997 Atlanta Braves season|1997]], while the Expos played there from 1969 to 1972 and from 1981 to 1997. The stadium was constructed in 1962 to replace midtown [[Connie Mack Field]], which had been the West Palm Beach spring training home of the [[History of the Oakland Athletics|Philadelphia and Kansas City Athletics]] from 1946 to 1962. The first game was played on Saturday, March 9, 1963, under overcast skies and extremely high winds which blew sand from the outfield areas, directly toward seating area, which were not as yet totally landscaped at that time. Mayor C. Ben Holleman threw out the first ball and the [[1963 Kansas City Athletics season|Kansas City Athletics]] defeated the Milwaukee Braves 3-0 in front of a medium sized crowd of 3,265 fans. [[Warren Spahn]] started for Milwaukee and was the losing pitcher.{{cite news |title='WPB' A's Spoil Braves' Municipal Stadium Debut |author=Bob Balfe |newspaper=The Palm Beach Post|date=1963-03-10 |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=6_8iAAAAIBAJ&sjid=dswFAAAAIBAJ&pg=1044,2048216&dq=west+palm+beach+municipal+stadium&hl=en|accessdate=|page=E1}} The ballpark later hosted the 1982 and 1992 Florida State League All-Star Games.{{cite news |title=MAJOR TALENT SHOW: ALL-STARS COME OUT TONIGHT AT STADIUM|author=Dave George|newspaper=The Palm Beach Post|date=1992-06-27 |url=|accessdate=|page=1C}} Atlanta and Montreal played their final spring training game at the ballpark on Wednesday March 26, 1997, which saw Montreal come through with a 2-0 victory.{{cite news |title=Around the NL|author=|newspaper=St. Petersburg Times|date=1997-03-27 |url=|accessdate=|page=5C}} The stadium was later demolished in 2002 and there is nothing to mark its former place, which is now covered by a [[Home Depot]] location. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{Atlanta Braves}} {{Montreal Expos}} {{FSL ballparks}} {{Senior Professional Baseball Association}} [[Category:Atlanta Braves spring training venues]] [[Category:Florida State League ballparks]] [[Category:Milwaukee Braves spring training venues]] [[Category:Defunct minor league baseball venues]] [[Category:Montreal Expos spring training venues]] [[Category:Defunct baseball venues in the United States]] [[Category:Grapefruit League venues]] [[Category:Baseball venues in Florida]] [[Category:Spring training ballparks]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in West Palm Beach, Florida]] [[Category:Sports venues in Palm Beach County, Florida]] [[Category:1963 establishments in Florida]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1963]] [[Category:2002 disestablishments in Florida]] [[Category:Sports venues demolished in 2002]] [[Category:Demolished sports venues in Florida]] {{Florida-baseball-venue-stub}}

{{Unreferenced|date=December 2009}} {{Infobox Stadium | stadium_name = Young Arena | nickname = | image = | location = 125 Commercial Street
Waterloo, IA 50701 | broke_ground = | opened = December 1994 | owner = City of Waterloo | operator = City of Waterloo | construction_cost = $4.3 million
(${{formatprice|{{Inflation|US|4300000|1994}}}} in {{Inflation-year|US}} dollars{{inflation-fn|US}}) | architect = InVision Architects | general_contractor= Gardner Construction | former_names = | seating_capacity = 3,500 (ice hockey) | tenants = [[Waterloo Black Hawks]] ([[USHL]]) (1994–present) }} '''Young Arena''' is a 3,000-seat multi-purpose arena in [[Waterloo, Iowa]], [[United States]], and was built in 1994. It is home to the [[Waterloo Black Hawks]] of the [[United States Hockey League]], the Waterloo Warriors of the [[Midwest High School Hockey League]], the [[Waterloo Youth Hockey Association]], the [[University of Northern Iowa Club Hockey Team]], and the [[Cedar Valley Figure Skating Club]]. Young Arena has also hosted the NCAA Division III wrestling championships and occasional basketball games. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.waterlooleisureservices.org/ya/ Official website] {{USHL Arenas}} {{Coord|42|29|56|N|92|20|37|W|type:landmark|display=title}} [[Category:Sports venues in Iowa]] [[Category:Indoor arenas in Iowa]] [[Category:Indoor ice hockey venues in the United States]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Waterloo, Iowa]] [[Category:Tourist attractions in Black Hawk County, Iowa]] [[Category:1994 establishments in Iowa]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1994]] [[Category:Figure skating venues in the United States]] [[Category:Basketball venues in Iowa]] [[Category:College wrestling venues in the United States]] {{Iowa-stadium-stub}}
